The '''American Pet Products Association''' <ref>[http://finance.google.com/finance?cid=6878064 Google Finance]</ref><ref>[http://www.americanpetproducts.org APPA Website]</ref> ('''APPA''') is a not-for-profit industry association founded in 1958 and is headquartered in [[Stamford, Connecticut]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.americanpetproducts.org/about_staff.asp|title=Staff Member Directory|website=American Pet Products Association|access-date=2018-08-24}}</ref>[[Stamford, Connecticut|.]] The APPA represents more than 1000 pet product manufacturers, importers of pet products and suppliers of products for non-pet livestock as well.
APPMA supports the interests of its members through public policy, public affairs, and animal awareness. In 2008 it dropped the word ''Manufacturers'' from its name.<ref>[http://media.americanpetproducts.org/press.php?include=138698]</ref>
The APPA organizes the [[Global Pet Expo]] annually. The 2012 expo featured 896 exhibitors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/2012/3/prweb9318939.htm|title=Global Pet Expo, the World’s Largest Annual Pet Products Trade Show, Reports Record-Breaking Numbers in Attendance and Booths Sold|agency=PRWeb}}</ref>

{{italic title}} '''''Belorusy i rynok''''' ({{lang-ru|Белорусы и рынок}}, {{IPA-ru|bʲɛləˈrusɨ ɪ ˈrʲnək|pron}}) is the main business weekly newspaper published in [[Belarus]].
The newspaper was founded in 1990 under the name ''Belorusskij rynok'' (Белорусский рынок, ''The Belarusian Market'') and was one of the first private media in Belarus.
In 2005 the newspaper had to change its name following a decree of president [[Lukashenka]] that forbid usage of the words ''National'' and ''Belarusian'' in names of organisations and newspapers.
Current chief editor is [[Viačasłaŭ Chadasoŭski]].
The newspaper is published mainly in [[Russian language]].

[[File:BIOlogovertical.jpg|thumb|right]] {{press release|date=January 2018}} The '''Biotechnology Innovation Organization''' ('''BIO''') is the largest [[trade organization]] in the world that represents the [[biotechnology]] industry.<ref>Anna Edney, [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-06-19/biosciences-defy-u-s-jobs-slump-as-research-labs-hire.html "Biosciences Defy U.S. Jobs Slump as Research Labs Hire"], ''Bloomberg News'', June 19, 2012.</ref><ref>European Biotechnology Network. [http://www.european-biotechnology.net/services/linklist/european-and-international-biotech-industry-associations.html "List of European and International Biotech Industry Associations"]</ref><ref>[http://www.genengnews.com/gen-articles/gen-s-30th-anniversary-biotech-trade-associations/3695/ "GEN's 30th Anniversary: Biotech Trade Associations"], ''Genetic Engineering News'', June 15, 2011.</ref> On January 4, 2016 the Biotechnology Industry Organization changed its name to be the Biotechnology Innovation Organization.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Biotechnology Innovation Organization changes name to Biotechnology Innovation Organization {{!}} Business Wire|url = http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20160104006245/en/Biotechnology-Industry-Organization-Biotechnology-Innovation-Organization|website = www.businesswire.com|accessdate = 2016-01-04}}</ref>
==Activities== ===Trade meetings=== BIO holds a trade meeting each year in the United States, which are essential for the business development and partnering activities that are required in the biotechnology sector, in which it is expensive to develop products, timelines to develop products are long, and regulatory risks are high.<ref>Robert Weisman, [https://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2013/04/22/biotechnology-executives-from-around-world-gather-chicago-amid-changing-times/Rzvxhh2ZMWW42yh1El3TNJ/story.html "Biopharmaceutical industry faces a shift in dynamics"], ''Boston Globe'', April 23, 2013.</ref> In 2018 the BIO International Convention was held in [[Boston]] and was attended by 18,289 delegates from 49 states, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico and 67 countries.<ref>BIO Press Office. June 7, 2018 [http://convention.bio.org/content.aspx?id=6875 BIO2018: By The Numbers]</ref> The event also held over 46,916 One-On-One Partnering Meetings, becoming a Guiness World Records, Record Holder for the "Largest Business Partnering Event."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bio.org/press-release/bio-sets-guinness-world-records%E2%84%A2-title-largest-business-partnering-event|title=BIO Sets the GUINNESS WORLD RECORDS™ Title for the Largest Business Partnering Event - BIO|website=BIO|language=en|access-date=2018-07-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://convention.bio.org/content.aspx?id=6875|title=BIO 2018: By the Numbers {{!}} 2018 BIO International Convention|website=convention.bio.org|access-date=2018-07-02}}</ref>
It also holds regional partnering meetings, for example in [[China]],<ref>[http://www.biosciencetechnology.com/news/2013/04/biotechnology-industry-organization-bio-and-china-center-pharmaceutical-international-exchange-ccpie-announce-strategic-partnership-expand-bio-convention-china#.UbPr4vYaePU "The Biotechnology Innovation Organization (BIO) and the China Center for Pharmaceutical International Exchange (CCPIE) Announce Strategic Partnership to Expand the BIO Convention in China"], BIO Press Office. April 18, 2013</ref> [[India]],<ref>[http://news.thomasnet.com/companystory/BIO-India-Conference-showcases-growing-Indian-biotech-industry-583422 "BIO India Conference showcases growing Indian biotech industry"], BIO Press Release. September 7, 2010.</ref> and Europe.<ref>Staff, Flanders BIO. [http://flandersbio.be/events/bio-europe-2013/ "BIO-Europe® 2013 - 19th Annual International Partnering Meeting"]</ref>
===Lobbying=== In 2013 it spent $1.98 million on [[lobbying]] in the United States.<ref>Staff, The Center for Responsive Politics. [http://www.opensecrets.org/lobby/clientsum.php?id=D000024369 "Lobbying: Biotechnology Innovation Organization"], Page Accessed June 7, 2013</ref> Issues included the amending the [[Internal Revenue Code]] to provide an exception from the passive loss rules for investments in high-technology research small business [[Flow-through entity|pass-through entities]], to include [[vaccine]]s against [[seasonal influenza]] within the definition of taxable vaccines, and to extend, expand, and improve the qualifying therapeutic discovery project program that first became law in 2010.<ref>The Center for Responsive Politics, [http://www.opensecrets.org/lobby/clientbills.php?id=D000024369&year=2013 "Bills lobbied"], Page Accessed June 7, 2013</ref><ref>Drew Armstrong, [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-05-21/biotechnology-drugs-may-earn-5-million-u-s-tax-credit-to-aid-development.html "Promising' Biotechnology Medicines May Earn $5 Million U.S. Tax Credit"], ''Bloomberg News'', May 21, 2010.</ref>
Examples of its public lobbying efforts, include support for development of [[Biofuel|biofuels such as those produced from algae,]]<ref>Kambiz Foroohar for Bloomberg News. June 3, 2010. [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-06-03/exxon-600-million-algae-investment-spurs-khosla-to-dismiss-as-pipe-dream.html Exxon $600 Million Algae Investment Makes Khosla See Pipe Dream]</ref> [[Biofuel|genetically modified crops]],<ref>Elaine Watson, [http://www.foodnavigator-usa.com/People/Biotechnology-Industry-Organization-It-s-not-too-late-to-change-the-conversation-on-GMOs "It's not too late to change the conversation on GMOs: Interview with Cathy Enright, Executive VP for Food and Biotechnology, BIO"], ''Food Navigator'', May 20, 2013.</ref> strong [[intellectual property]] rights,<ref>Victoria Slind-Flor, [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-12-03/lg-dupont-bank-of-america-aero-intellectual-property.html "LG, DuPont, Bank of America, GM: Intellectual Property"], ''Bloomberg News'', December 3, 2012.</ref> and for a more efficient and predictable regulatory process for new food and drug products.<ref>Robert Weisman, [https://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2012/06/18/fda-under-spotlight-biotechnology-industry-organization-bio-convention-opens-boston/JW4lLh22mJwPN5ot2z8MtJ/story.html "Federal drug review nettles biotech industry"], ''Boston Globe'', June 19, 2012.</ref>
===Alliances=== In June 2013 BIO partnered with the [[Coalition of Small Business Innovators]] to lobby the U.S. government to modernize the U.S. tax code "to recognize and promote small business innovation as fundamental to the long-term growth of the U.S. economy".<ref name=CSBI/><ref>[http://www.smallbusinessinnovators.org/page.asp?id=19 "Coalition of Small Business Innovators Official Website"]</ref>
It is a member of The Alliance to Feed the Future, an umbrella network, the mission of which is to "raise awareness and improve understanding of the benefits & necessity of modern food production and technology in order to meet global demand".<ref>[http://www.alliancetofeedthefuture.org/AbouttheAlliance.aspx Alliance to Feed the Future Official Website] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130511040732/http://www.alliancetofeedthefuture.org/AbouttheAlliance.aspx |date=May 11, 2013 }}</ref><ref>PR Web. Monday, March 18, 2013 [http://www.sfgate.com/business/prweb/article/Alliance-to-Feed-the-Future-Congratulates-Our-4364162.php#ixzz2VgNNDSLo "Alliance to Feed the Future Congratulates Our Farmers, Supports Education for Future Generations on National Agriculture Day"]</ref>
==Organization== ===Members=== [[File:James Greenwood 2017 President of Bio DSC8468.JPG | thumb | right | James C. Greenwood, President of BIO, 2017]] BIOs members include companies that make [[Pharmaceutical drugs]], [[biofuels]], [[industrial enzymes]], and [[genetically modified crops]].<ref>[http://www.biospace.com/company_profile.aspx?CompanyId=1311 "BIO profile at Biospace"]</ref> As of 2016, it represents 1,100 biotech companies in all 50 U.S. states, which employ 1.61 million Americans and support an additional 3.4 million jobs.<ref name="CSBI">[http://blog.gcase.org/2013/06/04/biotechnology-industry-organization-joins-coalition-of-small-business-innovators/ "Biotechnology Innovation Organization Joins Coalition of Small Business Innovators"], BIO Press Release, June 4, 2013.</ref>
===Leadership=== BIO was founded 1993 in [[Washington, D.C.]] and [[Carl B. Feldbaum]] was the president from BIO's founding until he retired in 2004,<ref>{{cite press release |title=BIO President Carl Feldbaum to Retire at Year End |publisher=Biotechnology Innovation Organization |date=2 February 2004 |url=http://www.prnewswire.com/cgi-bin/stories.pl?ACCT=104&STORY=/www/story/02-02-2004/0002100951&EDATE= |accessdate=15 July 2009}}</ref> and was succeeded by [[James C. Greenwood]]. As of 2018, John Maraganore, PhD., president and chief executive officer of [[Alnylam Pharmaceuticals]], Inc., was chairman and <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.alnylam.com/about-alnylam/alnylam-leadership/|title=Our Leadership|last=|first=|date=|website=www.alnylam.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=2018-07-02}}</ref> James Greenwood was president and CEO.<ref>Staff, BIO [http://www.bio.org/senior-staff BIO Senior Staff] Page Accessed June 7, 2013</ref>
==Biotechnology Heritage Award== The [[Biotechnology Heritage Award]], presented annually at the Biotechnology Innovation Organization (BIO) Annual International Convention by the Biotechnology Innovation Organization (BIO) and the [[Science History Institute]] (formerly the Chemical Heritage Foundation), recognizes individuals who have made significant contributions to the development of biotechnology through discovery, innovation, and public understanding.<ref name=CHF>{{cite web|title= Biotechnology Heritage Award|url=https://www.sciencehistory.org/node/285|website=[[Science History Institute]]|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>

{{citation style|date=February 2017}} The '''British Iron and Steel Federation''' ('''BISF'''), formed in 1934, was an organisation of British iron and steel producers responsible for the national planning of steel production. Its creation was imposed on the industry by [[Ramsay MacDonald]]'s [[National Government 1931–1935|National Government]] as a precondition to the establishment of steel import tariffs. It was a successor to the National Federation of Iron and Steel Manufacturers, formed in 1918.
Sir William James Larke was the first director of the federation.
It continued to exist until 1967 when the industry was nationalised as [[British Steel Corporation]] during [[Harold Wilson]]'s first term in government.

In vitro contract research }} '''Caliper, A PerkinElmer Company''' is based in [[Hopkinton, Massachusetts]] with direct sales, service and application-support operations in countries around the globe. Founded in 1995, Caliper develops products and services to the life sciences research community, including [[pharmaceutical]] and [[biotechnology]] companies, and government and other not-for profit research institutions. Caliper’s integrated systems, consisting of instruments, software and [[reagents]], [[laboratory automation]] tools and [[drug discovery]] assay services enable researchers to better understand the basis for disease and more effectively discover safe and effective drugs. Caliper’s product portfolio includes, [[microfluidics]], lab automation & liquid handling, optical imaging technologies, and [[drug discovery]] & [[drug development]] outsourcing solutions. == Microfluidic platform == Caliper is a pioneer in [[microfluidic]] [[lab-on-a-chip]] technology which represents a significant advancement in laboratory experimentation, bringing the benefits of miniaturization, integration and automation to numerous research-based industries. Caliper’s proprietary microfluidic sipper chips are a high-throughput complement to the planar chips which Caliper manufactures for the Agilent Bioanalyzer 2100. The microfluidic technology forms the basis of Caliper’s LabChip EZ reader systems used for drug screening and profiling and the LabChip GX series for molecular biology [[DNA]], [[RNA]] and [[protein analysis]]. == Optical imaging == Through its acquisition of Xenogen Corporation in 2006, Caliper is now a developer of [[in vivo]] biophotonic imaging technology, which allows for real-time, non-invasive exploration of [[genes]], proteins, pathogens, and tumor cells in living animals.{{cite journal | title=Advancing bioluminescence imaging technology for the evaluation of anticancer agents in the MDA-MB-435-HAL-Luc mammary fat pad and subrenal capsule tumor models.| date=2009-01-01 | publisher=| pmid=19118051| doi=10.1158/1078-0432.CCR-08-0897| volume=15| issue=1| journal=Clin. Cancer Res.| pages=238–46}} Caliper offers a complement of patented biophotonic and fluorescent imaging technologies, as well as genetically modified animal programs. Caliper’s imaging product lines include a suite of IVIS imaging systems - many measuring both bioluminescence and fluorescence, ''in vivo'' imaging reagents, specialized light producing animal models, and genetic modification programs for pharmaceutical and biotechnology research and development. In a recent Japanese study, the IVIS imaging system was used to evaluate the binding affinity and RNA interference ([[RNAi]]) of LMWC/[[siRNA]] complexes.{{cite journal | title=Evaluation of the binding affinity and RNA interference of low-molecular-weight chitosan/siRNA complexes using an imaging system | date=2008-10-30 | publisher=| pmid=19337002 | volume=129 | issue=4 | journal=Yakugaku Zasshi | pages=475–84 | doi=10.1248/yakushi.129.475}} == Lab automation and liquid handling == Caliper has held a long standing position in laboratory automation starting with the introduction of the world’s first lab robotic system, the Zymark Zymate. To date, Caliper has a number of lab automation and liquid handling systems for the life sciences industry. In January 2009, the Zephyr Genomics Workstation was introduced which promises to deliver a benchtop solution for automating routine but critical processes for [[molecular biology]] such as [[nucleic acid purification]], reaction setup and normalization. In addition to automating molecular biology, Caliper has many other [[robotic]] systems including the Zephyr SPE and RapidTrace SPE workstations to automate [[solid phase extraction]] and several liquid handling and plate management systems including the Sciclone ALH 3000 liquid handler and Twister II systems to automate drug discovery and development. Caliper also custom designs integrated vendor-neutral instruments and software such as the Twister II - LightCycler (Roche) integrated system which fully automates real-time [[PCR]]. == Discovery and development outsourcing solutions == Caliper’s Discovery Alliances & Services division (CDAS) was created from the acquisitions of NovaScreen, a provider of [[in vitro]] & [[in vivo]] discovery services. CDAS develops, utilizes, and provides a comprehensive array of services to improve the productivity, accelerate the pace, and reduce the cost of the [[drug discovery]] process. The ''in vitro'' service arm of CDAS includes a comprehensive array of ''in vitro'' drug discovery and development solutions including more than 1000 screening [[assays]] that help define the mode of action, side effect profiles, selectivity, and other relevant activities of drug candidates. ''In vivo'' capabilities include: non-invasive ''in vivo'' [[optical imaging]], OncoMouse studies, and ''in vivo'' compound evaluations for safety assessment and [[drug repositioning]]. == History == Caliper Life Sciences was founded in 1995 by [[Larry Bock]] and Drs. Michael Knapp, Michael Ramsey and Andreas Manz. as Caliper Technologies with a strong focus on microfluidics technology. In 2003, Caliper acquired Zymark a leader in laboratory automation and robotics and Caliper Life Sciences was born. In October 2005, Caliper acquired NovaScreen Biosciences Corporation a privately held CRO offering pre-clinical drug discovery and development services. NovaScreen’s services included ''in vitro'' compound profiling for safety assessment, drug discovery screening services for targets such as GPCRs, Kinases, Ion Channels, Transporters, Nuclear Receptors and customized assay development services. In August 2006, Caliper acquired Xenogen Corporation, a developer of ''in vivo'' optical imaging systems (IVIS systems) and its division, Xenogen Biosciences a CRO offering ''in vivo'' transgenic animal production, phenotyping, gene targeting and ''in vivo'' optical imaging services. At the end of October 2008, SOTAX—a tester and software developer of medical devices—acquired Caliper's Pharmaceutical Development & Quality Analysis (PDQ) Division for $15.8 Million.{{cite news | title=Caliper sells biz unit for $15.8M to SOTAX | date=2008-10-30 | publisher=Mass High Tech | url=http://www.masshightech.com/stories/2008/10/27/daily33-Caliper-sells-biz-unit-for-158M-to-SOTAX.html}}{{cite news | title=Caliper Grabs $15.8M In Product Line Sale | date=2008-10-30 | publisher=Worcester Business Journal | url=http://www.wbjournal.com/news41938.html}} Shortly thereafter on November 10, 2008, Caliper's AutoTrace(r) line of product was acquired by [[Dionex]].{{cite news | title=Dionex Enters Into Agreement With Caliper Life Sciences to Acquire Product Line for Water Sample Preparation | date=2008-11-10 | publisher=MarketWatch | url=http://www.marketwatch.com/news/story/Dionex-Enters-Into-Agreement-With/story.aspx?guid=28223301-9045-48B7-A4B0-FEF2C02E2C73}} In December 2009, [[Taconic Biosciences]] acquired XenoGen Biosciences ''in vivo'' pre-clinical CRO subsidiary of Caliper Life Sciences.{{cite news | title=Taconic Acquires Xenogen Biosciences Subsidiary of Caliper Life Sciences| date=2009-12-14 | publisher=Taconic | url=http://www.taconic.com/resources/newsroom/2009/xenogen-biosciences}} A year later in December 2010, Caliper purchased Cambridge Research & Instrumentation Inc. for about $20 million in a cash and stock deal.{{cite news | title=Caliper buying Cambridge Research for $20 million | date=2010-12-09 | publisher=Bloomberg | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-12-09/caliper-buying-cambridge-research-for-20-million.html}} In September 2011, PerkinElmer agreed to buy Caliper Life Sciences for $600 million.{{cite news | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/09/08/perkinelmer-caliper-idUSN1E7861IY20110908 | title = PerkinElmer to buy Caliper for $600 mln | author = Reuters | accessdate = 2011-09-08 | date=2011-09-08}} On November 7, 2011, PerkinElmer completed the acquisition of Caliper Life Sciences for a total net purchase price of approximately $600 million in cash.{{cite web | url = http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20111107006528/en/PerkinElmer-Completes-Acquisition-Caliper-Life-Sciences | title = PerkinElmer Completes Acquisition of Caliper Life Sciences | author = Business Wire | accessdate = 2011-11-07}} == Intellectual property == Caliper's portfolio of microfluidics-related patents has been ranked as high as #2 in technological strength in the Biotech/Pharma sector of the MIT Technology Review Patent Scorecard. Caliper actively out-licenses this portfolio as part of its Caliper Driven program to broaden and accelerate the availability of new technologies and products for life science and diagnostics applications. Licensing Caliper's microfluidic intellectual property benefits existing and potential partners by enhancing the strength of their product and service offerings through the incorporation of Caliper’s technology. Caliper also provides commercial and academic customers with proprietary methods via its Optical Imaging Patent Suite. The notification of allowance of Caliper’s patent claims for conjugate fluorescence imaging methods from the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office has added yet another valuable component to Caliper's widespread intellectual property estate. ==Acquisition history== * 1995 - Caliper Technologies Corporation is formed * 1999 - Caliper goes public in $75 Million offering * 2003 - Acquires Zymark * 2004 - Company changes name to Caliper Life Sciences * 2005 - Acquires NovaScreen Biosciences Corporation * 2006 - Acquires Xenogen * 2010 - Acquires Cambridge Research & Instrumentation Inc. * 2011 - Acquired by [[PerkinElmer]] ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.caliperls.com/}} * [http://finance.google.com/finance?q=calp&btnG=Search Caliper, A PerkinElmer Company] Company Profile at Google Finance. [[image:Logo capital.png|thumb|right]] '''''Capital''''' (''Capital'' in [[Romanian language|Romanian]]) is a Romanian financial and economic weekly magazine published in [[Bucharest]].<ref name="csee">{{cite book|title=Central and South-Eastern Europe 2004|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5J_gAU8c9NIC&pg=PA507|accessdate=9 May 2016|year=2003|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=978-1-85743-186-5|page=509}}</ref>
''Capital'' offers analyses, investigations and trend predictions accompanied by graphics, tables and photos to all with an interest in economics. Capital offers its readers guidance in their entrepreneurial initiatives, going beyond the news in order to discover the causes that generate the events.
''Capital'' was the first publication launched by Ringier in Romania. It was started in 1990.<ref name="csee"/> ''Capital'' was re-launched in 2000 and 2004 in a new and modern graphic concept. Capital has launched the [[Capital Top 300 wealthiest men in Romania|Top 300 Richest Romanians]]. Other two tops were added in the following years: Top 100 Successful Women and in 2005 Top 100 Companies to Work for.
''Capital'' is created by: * Iulian Bortos - Editor-in-Chief; * Oana Osman - Deputy Editor-in-Chief; * Paul Lacatus - Senior Managing Editor; * Mihaela Stanculescu - Marketing Manager; * Mirela Murariu - Advertising Manager; * Claudiu Serban - Executive Director; * Anca Chilom - Capital Top. * Editors: Vali Birzoi, Aurel Dragan, Ana-Maria Smadeanu, Gabriela Tinteanu Moldoveanu, Razvan Amariei, Razvan Zamfir, Robert Stan, Ovidiu Anton, Mona Scarisoreanu, Consuela Stegarescu, Diana Zaharia, Mirona Hritcu, Cristina Mocanu, Catalina Tatu and others.

''Capital'' issues the following supplements: * Gadget * European Funds * Banking * Buildings&Real Estate * Foreign Investments * Financial services
'''Brand extensions''': The magazine publishes in Romania the Top Capital Collection: * Top 300 Richest Romanian People * Top 100 Most Successful Women * Top 100 Companies to Work for * Top 120 Best Franchises in Romania
'''TV Shows:''' * Capital TV on Kanal D.
'''Capital TV sections''': * Behind the economy curtains * Capital expert * People on top * Trends

'''Construction accounting''' is a form of [[project accounting]] applied to construction projects. See also [[production accounting]]. Construction accounting is a vitally necessary form of accounting, especially when multiple [[contracts]] come into play. The construction field uses many terms not used in other forms of accounting, such as "draw" and [http://www.investopedia.com/terms/p/progress-billings.asp progress billing]<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.investopedia.com/terms/p/progress-billings.asp|title=Progress Billings|last=Staff|first=Investopedia|date=2011-01-02|work=Investopedia|access-date=2017-10-22|language=en-US}}</ref>. Construction accounting may also need to account for vehicles and equipment, which may or may not be owned by the company as a [[fixed asset]]. Construction accounting requires [[invoicing]] and [[vendor]] [[payment]], more or less as to the amount of [[business]] done.
In the United States, the authoritative literature on Construction accounting is [[AICPA Statements of Position|AICPA Statement of Position]] [http://clio.lib.olemiss.edu/cdm/ref/collection/aicpa/id/3678 SOP 81-1].
== Construction Costs == These are all cost related to the construction process, right from materials, labor costs, consultancy and all management expenses. Construction accounting involves charging construction costs to the applicable contract. Costs fall into three categories. [[Direct costs]] are labor, material, and subcontracting costs, land.<ref>AICPA SOP 81-1 Para. 72 a.</ref> [[Indirect costs]] include indirect labor, supervision, tools, equipment costs, supplies, insurance, and support costs.<ref>AICPA SOP 81-1 Para. 72 b.</ref> Selling, general and administrative costs, are generally excluded from contract costs.<ref>AICPA SOP 81-1 Para. 72 c,d.</ref>
== Revenue Recognition ==
Construction accounting requires unique [[revenue recognition]] rules for contracts in progress.
In most cases, revenue is recognized using the Percentage of Completion Method. Under this method, revenue is recognized using an estimate for the overall anticipated profit for a particular contract multiplied by the estimated percent complete of that contract.<ref>AICPA SOP 81-1 Para. 22-25</ref> This involves the inherent risk of relying upon estimates.<ref>SOP 81-1 Para. 26-29</ref>
An example of a Percentage of Completion Method:
A construction company has entered into contract to construct a building for $10,000,000. The building was completed in 2020.
2018 2019 2020 Contract Price $10,000,000 $10,000,000 $10,000,000 Actual cost to date $2,291,000 $6,146,000 $10,211,000 Estimated cost to complete $5,609,000 $4,210,000 $0 Total estimated cost $7,900,000 $10,356,000 $10,211,000 Estimated gross profit (loss) (actual in 2020) $2,100,000 $(356,000) $(211,000)
Revenue Recognition:
2018: $2,291,000 / $7,900,000 = 29% * $10,000,000 = $2,900,000
2019: $6,146,000 / $10,356,000 = 59% * $10,000,000 - $2,900,000 = $3,000,000
2020: $10,000,000 - $5,900,000 = $4,100,000
Gross Profit:
2018: $2,900,000 - $2,291,000 = $609,000
2019: $(356,000) - $609,000 = $(956,000)
2020: $(211,000) - $(956,000) - $609,000 = $145,000<ref>{{cite book|last1=Spiceland|first1=David|title=Intermediate Accounting|publisher=McGraw Hill|edition=9}}</ref>
When using the Percentage of Completion Method you start with the contract price in this example is $10,000,000 for the entire job. The job is to be completed in three years. To record the first years revenue you start with computing the 2018 actual cost to date divided by the total estimated cost to get the percentage of completion for 2018 which is 29% of the job completed in 2018. You than take the 29% multiply by the cost of the job $10,000,000 and you get $2,900,000 of revenue fore 2018. To compute 2019 you take the same steps you take the actual cost to date of $6,146,000 divide it by total estimated cost of $10,356,000 and you get 59%. That is the percentage of the job completed in 2019. Now you take 59% multiply by contract price of $10,000,000 then subtract the previous years revenue of $2,900,000 and 2019 revenue recognized is $3,000,000. For 2020 you take the contract price of $10,000,000 and subtract the total of both previous years revenue which is $5,900,000 to get 2020 completed revenue of $4,100,000. To compute the gross profit for 2018 you take 2018 revenue of $2,900,000 and subtract the actual cost to date of $2,291,000 to get a gross profit of $609,000 for 2018. For 2019 you take the estimated gross profit form the table of $(356,000) subtract the 2018 gross profit total of $609,000 and you get $(956,000) for 2019. 2020 gross profit you take the estimated gross profit from the table of $(211,000) subtract the previous years of $(956,000) and $609,000 and you get $145,000 of gross profit.
Under SOP 81-1, revenue is also allowed to be computed using the Completed Contract Method.<ref>SOP 81-1 Para. 30</ref> Under this method, contract revenues and costs are not recognized until the contract is substantially complete. However, this method is not allowable if the results are significantly different than results using the Percentage of Completion Method.<ref>SOP 81-1 Para. 31</ref> The Completed Contract Method is allowed in circumstances in which reasonable estimates cannot be determined.<ref>SOP 81-1 Para. 32</ref> However, these types of circumstances can be construed as a lack of internal control.

In [[Canadian contract law]], '''Contract A''' is a concept that has recently been applied by courts regarding the fair and equal treatment of bidders in a [[contract tendering process]]. Essentially this concept formalizes previously applied precedents and strengthens the protection afforded to those who submit bids in the tendering process. The concept was introduced in 1981 by the [[Supreme Court of Canada]], in ''[[R. v. Ron Engineering and Construction (Eastern) Ltd]]''<ref>Government Procurement, Fourth Edition, by Paul Emanuelli, p. 125, Published by Lexis Nexis Canada, Year of Publication: 2017, {{ISBN|978-0-433-47454-8}}</ref>. The court found that a "[[duty of fairness]]" was owed to all bidders by an owner in a tendering process.
The Contract A is formed when a "request for proposal" is responded to in the form of a valid bid, sometimes also known as submission of price. As many Contracts A are formed between the owner (person, company or organization tendering the project) and the bidders as their bids are received. The owner must now deal fairly and equally with all bidders, and must not show any favouritism or [[prejudice]] towards any bidder(s). In essence, this concept boils down to the right of an individual to have equal opportunity to be successful with their bid for work.
A breach of Contract A may occur if the owner (or an owner's officer or representative, see [[vicarious liability]]), provides information, changes specification during the tendering process to unfairly benefit a particular bidder, enters into closed negotiations with an individual bidder in an effort to obtain more desirable contract conditions, etc. The most common situation in which an owner is accused of having breached Contract A occurs when a bidder is selected who is not the lowest bidder. This contravenes established custom and practice, which would normally dictate that the lowest bid be awarded the contract, but is not normally a source of a breach if handled properly. The successful suits for breach typically occur if the lowest bidder has been excluded based on a stipulation not clearly outlined in the tender documents (such as preference for local bidders) or when the [[Privilege Clause]] employed by the owner to exclude a principle of custom and practice is judged by the courts to be too broadly worded to have any meaning.

{{Infobox person | name = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Daniel-Gérard Rouzier | birth_date = | baptism_date = | birth_place = [[Pétion-Ville]], [[Haiti]] | disappeared_date = | disappeared_place = | disappeared_status = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | body_discovered = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | monuments = | residence = Pétion-Ville, Haiti | nationality = Haitian | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = Economics | alma_mater = [[Dartmouth College]]
[[Georgetown University]] | occupation = Economist, entrepreneur, philanthropist | years_active = | organization = [[Food For The Poor]] ([[NGO]]) | agent = | notable_works = Vision or Illusion; The Might of the Ideas; Faith, Love, and Hope | style = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = | height = | weight = | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = Sun Auto, E-Power, PromoCapital Bank | spouse = Karine Abraham Rouzier | partner = | children = 3 | parents = Gérard Raoul Rouzier (father)
Marie-Hélène Brun (mother) | relatives = [[Fabrice Rouzier]] (brother) | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = }} '''Daniel Gérard Rouzier''' (b. Pétion-Ville, 1960) is a [[Haiti]]an tycoon. Rouzier runs several companies in different sectors in Haiti, including car dealers, and an electric power company;{{cite news|title=Haiti - Politic : Michel Martelly has designated Daniel-Gérard Rouzier as Prime Minister |url=http://www.haitilibre.com/en/news-2999-haiti-politic-michel-martelly-has-designated-daniel-gerard-rouzier-as-prime-minister.html |accessdate=7 May 2014|newspaper=Haïti Libre |date=20 May 2011}} and is member of the executive board of [[PromoCapital]]; a Haitian bank. Rouzier is member of the Haitian-American Chamber of Commerce (AMCHAM). ==Biography== Born into an elite [[Mulatto Haitians|mulatto]] family, Rouzier was alumnus of [[Institution Saint-Louis de Gonzague]], the most prestigious school in Haiti. His father, Gérard Rouzier, was a jurist, president of the [[Haitian Football Federation]], Vice President of [[CONCACAF]], and Minister of Sports and Youth in the dictatorship of [[Jean-Claude Duvalier]] in the 1970s.{{cite web|url=http://www.haitianalysis.com/2011/5/12/daniel-g-rard-rouzier-neoliberal-champion-to-be-tapped-for-premier |title=Daniel Gérard Rouzier: Neoliberal champion to be tapped for premier |date=12 May 2011 |publisher=HaitianAlysis.com |accessdate=7 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110813082502/http://www.haitianalysis.com/2011/5/12/daniel-g-rard-rouzier-neoliberal-champion-to-be-tapped-for-premier |archivedate=August 13, 2011 |deadurl=no }}{{cite web|title=Análisis: Negocian ratificación de candidato a primer ministro en Haití|url=http://spanish.peopledaily.com.cn/31617/7394720.html|publisher=Pueblo en Línea - People’s Daily - 人民日报|accessdate=7 May 2014|language=Spanish|quote=Hijo del ministro de Deportes y de la Juventud durante el mandato de facto de Jean Claude Duvalier, Gérard Raoul Rouzier proviene de una familia vinculada a la política.}} One of his siblings is the renowned pianist [[Fabrice Rouzier]]. Rouzier graduated from the management and accounting at [[Dartmouth College]] and [[Georgetown University]] in the [[United States]].{{cite web|url=http://defend.ht/politics/articles/executive/992-martelly-chooses-daniel-gerard-rouzier-to-be-prime-minister |title=Martelly Chooses Daniel-Gérard Rouzier to be Prime Minister |date=16 May 2011 |publisher=defend.ht |accessdate=7 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120322071235/http://www.defend.ht/politics/articles/executive/992-martelly-chooses-daniel-gerard-rouzier-to-be-prime-minister |archivedate=22 March 2012 |df= }} He is an avid [[Association football|football]] player and a [[Bibliophilia|bibliophile]]. Rouzier, who has authored three books, owns one of the most complete libraries of Haiti,{{cite news |title=El empresario Daniel Gerard Rouzier es nombrado primer ministro de Haití |url=http://www.elmundo.es/america/2011/05/20/noticias/1305920269.html |accessdate=7 May 2014 |newspaper=El Mundo |date=20 May 2011 |agency=AFP |location=Port-au-Prince |language=Spanish}} and serves as a regular contributor to Haitian daily newspapers. Rouzier is a philanthropist, vice-president of the Haitian chapter of ''[[Food for the Poor]]'' and has provided food, housing, medical services, education to poor families within Haiti. ==Politics== Rouzier was a supporter of the [[2004 Haitian coup d'état|2004 coup d’etat]] that ousted President [[Jean-Bertrand Aristide]] for the second time, and accused him to be “one of the most violent rulers Haiti ever had,” and argued that Aristide’s “only intent seems to have only been to replace the dictators that preceded him rather than to promote real change in Haiti.” In 2010, he was appointed as Honorary Consul from Jamaica to Haiti.{{cite web |title=Daniel Rouzier Appointed as Honorary Consul for Jamaica to Haiti |url=http://www.foodforthepoor.org/newsroom/archive_10/daniel-rouzier-appointed.html |publisher=Food for the Poor |accessdate=7 May 2014 |location=Coconut Creek, Florida |date=2 June 2010}} On 15 May 2011, he was appointed Prime Minister by President [[Michel Martelly]] the day after his inauguration,{{cite news|title=Haiti - Politic : Martelly chooses Daniel Rouzier as Prime Minister|url=http://www.haitilibre.com/en/news-2962-haiti-politic-martelly-chooses-daniel-rouzier-as-prime-minister.html|accessdate=7 May 2014|newspaper=Haiti Libre|date=16 May 2011}} but the [[Chamber of Deputies (Haiti)|Chamber of Deputies of Haiti]], dominated by the Opposition, rejected his nomination on 21 June 2011{{cite news |title=Cámara rechaza a Daniel Rouzier |url=http://www.listin.com.do/las-mundiales/2011/6/21/193043/Camara-rechaza-a-Daniel-Rouzier |date= 21 June 2011 |accessdate=7 May 2014 |newspaper=Listín Diario |agency=Agencia EFE |location=Port-au-Prince |language=Spanish}} for allegedly paying only $600 in taxes during a five-year span while earning hundreds of millions of dollars.{{cite web|url=http://sentinel.ht/2017/07/09/energy-mafioso-chinas-2b-plan-electrify-haiti/ |title="Energy Mafioso" against China’s $2B Plan to Electrify Haiti |editor=Maxime, Samuel |date=9 July 2017 |publisher=Haiti Sentinel |accessdate=10 July 2017}} President Martelly has expressed disappointment with the deputies, but he accepted it.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-13872311 |title=Haiti parliament rejects President Martelly's PM choice |date= 22 June 2011 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=7 May 2014}} ==Personal life== Rouzier married Karine Abraham and had three children. In 2005, his wife was kidnapped and held for more than ten days; Abraham was released after the payment of a ransom and has lived abroad since then, in order to undergo therapy because of psychological problems due to this event. == Publications == * ''Vision ou Illusion'' (2000) * ''Le Pouvoir des Idees'' (2002) * ''Foi, Amour et Espoir'' (2006) == References == {{Reflist|30em|refs= {{cite news |title=Profil du Premier ministre désigné Daniel Gérard Rouzier |url=http://www.lematinhaiti.com/contenu.php?idtexte=23477 |accessdate=7 May 2014 |newspaper=Le Matin |date=23 May 2011 |language=French}} }} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rouzier, Daniel}} [[Category:1960 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Port-au-Prince]] [[Category:Haitian people of Mulatto descent]] [[Category:Haitian businesspeople]] [[Category:Haitian economists]] [[Category:Haitian non-fiction writers]] [[Category:Haitian male writers]] [[Category:Haitian diplomats]] [[Category:Columnists]]

{{Infobox football biography | name = David Gee | image = | caption = | fullname = David Gee | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Liverpool]], England | position = Manager | currentclub = | years1 = | clubs1 = | caps1 = | goals1 = | nationalyears1 = | nationalteam1 = | nationalcaps1 = | nationalgoals1 = | manageryears1 = 1997 | managerclubs1 = [[Toronto Lynx]] (general manager/assistant coach) | manageryears2 = 1998–2002 | managerclubs2 = [[Toronto Olympians]] }} '''David Gee''' is an English soccer head coach, [[businessman]] and League Administrator of the [[Ontario Soccer League]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Ontario Soccer League: About|url = http://www.ontariosl.com/PageDisplay.aspx?SideMenuID=110|website = www.ontariosl.com|accessdate = 2015-04-26|first = E2E|last = Soccer/Template}}</ref> He also serves as operations manager for [[League1 Ontario]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.league1ontario.com/contact|title=Contact|website=League1 Ontario|language=en-us|access-date=2017-02-05}}</ref>
== Managerial career == Gee began his managerial career in 1997 with the newly formed franchise the [[Toronto Lynx]] <nowiki/>of the [[USL A-League]]. He was given the position of general manager and assistant coach to head coach [[Peter Pinizzotto]]. He was primarily responsible for assembling and organizing the club's first roster. Gee brought in international imports [[Martin Dugas]], [[Gong Lei (footballer)|Lei Gong]], and [[Darren Tilley]], and local [[Canadian National Soccer League]] players.<ref>{{Cite web|title = type_Document_Title_here|url = http://www.rocketrobinsoccerintoronto.com/lynx0309.htm|website = www.rocketrobinsoccerintoronto.com|accessdate = 2015-04-26|publisher = Canada Kicks|last = Hendren|first = Paul}}</ref> The Lynx performed well in their debut season qualifying for a postseason berth. Later in the season Gee resigned from his position after differences with the team owners.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Canada Kicks -- News Story|url = http://www.rocketrobinsoccerintoronto.com/lynx0050.htm|website = www.rocketrobinsoccerintoronto.com |date=September 25, 1997 | accessdate = 2015-04-26|publisher = Canada Kicks|last = Hendren|first = Paul}}</ref> Gee was credited by team officials and players for organizing a capable team to perform in the A-League.<ref>{{Cite web|title = A-League - News Story|url = http://www.rocketrobinsoccerintoronto.com/lynx0018.htm|website = www.rocketrobinsoccerintoronto.com|date=June 7, 1997|accessdate = 2015-04-26|last = Hendren|first = Paul}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = A-League - News Story|url = http://www.rocketrobinsoccerintoronto.com/lynx0020.htm|website = www.rocketrobinsoccerintoronto.com|date=June 16, 1997|accessdate = 2015-04-26|last = Hendren|first = Paul}}</ref>
In 1998, Gee was appointed the head coach of the [[Toronto Olympians]] in the newly formed [[Canadian Professional Soccer League (1998-2005)|Canadian Professional Soccer League]]. He assembled yet another commendable squad primarily due to sponsorship money from [[Coffee Time]] and team owner [[Tom Michalopoulos]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Canada Kicks -- News Story|url = http://www.rocketrobinsoccerintoronto.com/98cpsl06.htm|website = www.rocketrobinsoccerintoronto.com|date=May 13, 1998|accessdate = 2015-04-26|last = Bailey|first = Dave}}</ref> He brought in several of his Toronto Lynx signings, players with USL experience, and top CNSL athletes.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Mississauga vs Toronto Olympians|url = http://www.rocketrobinsoccerintoronto.com/98cpsl20.htm|website = www.rocketrobinsoccerintoronto.com|date=|accessdate = 2015-04-26|last = Glover|first = Robin}}</ref> During his tenure with the organization he established Toronto as a powerhouse and a championship dynasty within the league. For his efforts the league awarded him the CPSL Coach of the Year award in 1998, and 1999.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Canada Kicks -- News Story: CPSL Awards Night |url=http://www.rocketrobinsoccerintoronto.com/98cpsl47.htm |website=www.rocketrobinsoccerintoronto.com |date=December 18, 1998 |accessdate=2015-04-26 |last=Bailey |first=Dave |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150709112755/http://www.rocketrobinsoccerintoronto.com/98cpsl47.htm |archivedate=July 9, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = 1999 CPSL Awards|url = http://www.rocketrobinsoccerintoronto.com/99cpsl77.htm|website = www.rocketrobinsoccerintoronto.com|date=|accessdate = 2015-04-26|last = Glover|first = Robin}}</ref> On June 20, 2001 he purchased the club from Coffee Time Donuts meanwhile retaining his position as head coach and general manager.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rocketrobinsoccerintoronto.com/01cpsl23.htm|title=Soccer team eyes move to Mississauga|last=LASKARIS|first=Sam|date=|website=www.rocketrobinsoccerintoronto.com|publisher=Scarborough Mirror|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=2015-04-26}}</ref> In 2002, Gee relocated his club to [[Mississauga]] and relinquished his role as head coach to Darren Tilley and Tony Laferrara in 2003.<ref>{{Cite web|title = June 13, 2003 Why Mississauga plays only road games (from CPSL website)|url = http://www.rocketrobinsoccerintoronto.com/reports03/03cpsl60.htm|website = www.rocketrobinsoccerintoronto.com|accessdate = 2015-04-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rocketrobinsoccerintoronto.com/reports03/03cpsl34.htm|title=Change rooms gone but soccer continues|last=|first=|date=|website=www.rocketrobinsoccerintoronto.com|publisher=Mississauga News|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=2015-04-26}}</ref> In 2004, Gee sold his club to John O'Neil, the Director of the Durham Region Soccer Association.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.zoominfo.com/p/David-Gee/428171329|title=David Gee {{!}} Ontario Soccer League {{!}} ZoomInfo.com|last=|first=|date=|website=ZoomInfo|publisher=Durham Region|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=2015-04-26}}</ref>
==Achievements== * '''[[Rogers Cup (soccer)|CPSL Championship]] (1):''' [[1999 Canadian Professional Soccer League season|1999]] * '''[[Open Canada Cup]] (3):''' 1998, 1999, 2000 * '''[[Canadian Soccer League (2006–present)|Canadian Professional Soccer League]] Regular Season Champions (3):''' 1998, 1999, 2000

{{DISPLAYTITLE:ExpertVoice}} {{notability|date=March 2017}} {{Infobox company | name = ExpertVoice | logo = ExpertVoice-logo-large-alt.png | type = [[Private company|Private]] | caption = | foundation = 2004 | location_city = [[Salt Lake City, Utah]] | location_country =
[[United States]] | industry = [[Technology]] | products = [[business software]], retail | homepage = [http://www.expertvoice.com/ www.expertvoice.com] }} '''ExpertVoice''' is a [[Salt Lake City, Utah]]-based company that helps brands and retailers improve product recommendations through education, product seeding and by offering first-hand product experience to retail sales associates and category-specific experts. ExpertVoice was previously named "Experticity".[http://www.crunchbase.com/company/experticity] ==History== The company was founded in 2004 by Paul Kirwin under the name 3point5, Inc. (referencing the fact that 3.5 feet was considered the optimal distance between two people in a one-one-one conversation).[http://www.snewsnet.com/news/3point5-promises-to-take-the-yawn-out-of-retail-training/] Kirwin's idea was to create an entertaining, web-based training platform for retail salespeople using brand discounts to incentivize them to complete training. Built on Kirwin’s television news background, Kirwin Productions was founded in 1985 and specialized in creating videos to train retail salespeople on a brand’s new technology and products.[http://www.deseretnews.com/article/8906/UTAH-TELEVISION-GRABS-22-EMMYS.html?pg=all] It was here that Kirwin got the idea of training retail salespeople online. In 2007, 3point5 acquired Influence Technologies, which among other things operated a discount marketplace for influencers called BroForm.com.[http://www.bicycleretailer.com/north-america/2007/10/16/3point5com-acquires-influence#.VDw949TaE6W] BroForm was renamed Promotive. In 2009, the company changed its name to SwarmBuilder.[http://www.bicycleretailer.com/north-america/2009/07/15/3point5com-changing-its-name#.U1WUw_ldWSp] The same year, it purchased a platform and named it ProMotive.com.[http://www.signalpeakvc.com/news/29/19/Parent-of-3point5-com-Re-named-SwarmBuilder] In 2010, the company was ranked 100th on Inc. magazine’s list of 500 Fastest Growing Companies.[http://www.deseretnews.com/article/700060194/14-Utah-companies-make-the-Inc-500-list.html?pg=all] In 2012, SwarmBuilder was rebranded as Experticity,[http://www.deseretnews.com/article/705397112/SwarmBuilder-rebrands-as-eXperticity-to-link-experts.html?pg=all] based on the idea that when buying a product, everyone wants to get advice from an expert. The name “Experticity” was purchased from an unrelated Seattle based-business.[http://www.vspring.com/news/91/19/SwarmBuilder-Rebrands-as-eXperticity] In March 2018, Experticity was renamed ExpertVoice, the name is meant to reflect the fact that consumers turn to the voices of experts for advice on what to buy.{{Cite news|url=https://www.experticity.com/experticity-now-expertvoice/|title=Experticity is now ExpertVoice - ExpertVoice|date=2018-03-13|work=ExpertVoice|access-date=2018-03-26|language=en-US}} ==Products== 3point5.com[http://www.crunchbase.com/company/3point5-com] trains retail sales associates across various industries through a patented “Edu-Game” format.[https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/01/25/idUS115441+25-Jan-2012+BW20120125] When sales associates complete Edu-Games demonstrating product knowledge, they are rewarded with gratis or discounted products from the brand sponsoring the training. ProMotive.com is an online marketplace for experts with significant personal and professional industry influence. ProMotive.com automates brand incentive programs and rewards industry professionals and influencers with product offers, discounts, samples and insider knowledge applicable to their field of expertise. Each of the Experticity platforms displays users’ expert score, which is a composite blend of product knowledge, purchases and professional experience.[https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/01/25/idUS115441+25-Jan-2012+BW20120125] ==Executive Leadership== Tom Stockham is the CEO of Experticity, having served on the company’s board of directors since 2007.[https://www.forbes.com/profile/thomas-stockham/] He was formerly CEO and president of [[Ancestry.com]] and president of [[Ticketmaster.com]]. == References == {{reflist}} http://www.crunchbase.com/company/experticity http://business.transworld.net/139870/features/retail-101-experticity-helps-educate-shop-staff-brands/ http://www.bicycleretailer.com/north-america/2009/07/15/3point5com-changing-its-name#.U1WUw_ldWSp http://www.signalpeakvc.com/news/29/19/Parent-of-3point5-com-Re-named-SwarmBuilder http://www.vspring.com/news/91/19/SwarmBuilder-Rebrands-as-eXperticity http://www.vspring.com/news/91/19/SwarmBuilder-Rebrands-as-eXperticityhttp://www.bizjournals.com/seattle/blog/techflash/2010/08/seattle_startup_experticity_ceases_operations_after_eight_years.html http://www.crunchbase.com/company/3point5-com https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/01/25/idUS115441+25-Jan-2012+BW20120125 https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/01/25/idUS115441+25-Jan-2012+BW20120125 https://www.reuters.com/article/2010/08/26/idUS116183+26-Aug-2010+BW20100826 https://www.forbes.com/profile/thomas-stockham/ ==External links== *{{official website|http://www.expertvoice.com}} [[Category:Business software]] [[Category:Business software companies]] [[Category:Service-oriented (business computing)]] [[Category:Marketing]]

{{Infobox book | name = Fierce Conversations: Achieving Success at Work and in Life One Conversation at a Time | orig title = | translator = | image = Fierce Conversations.jpg| author = Susan Scott | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = | published = 2002 The Berkley Trade Publishing Group | media_type = Print (Paperback) | pages = 320 | isbn = 0-425-19337-3 | dewey= | congress= BJ2121 .S42 2002 | oclc= | preceded_by = | followed_by = [[Fierce Leadership]]: A Bold Alternative to the Worst "Best" Practices of Business Today }}
'''''Fierce Conversations: Achieving Success at Work and in Life One Conversation at a Time''''' ({{ISBN|0-425-19337-3}}) is a [[self-help book]] written by Susan Scott, about how to have a difficult conversation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.astd.org/Publications/Blogs/Learning-Executive-Blog/2012/04/Book-Review-Fierce-Conversations |title=Book Review - Fierce Conversations |author=Steve Gladis |date=April 19, 2012 |work=Learning Executive Blog |publisher=[[American Society for Training & Development]] |accessdate=June 22, 2012}}</ref> The introduction states that ''Fierce Conversations'' is a "guide to tackling your toughest challenges and enriching relationships with everyone important to your success and happiness through principles, tools, and assignments designed to direct you through your first fierce conversations with yourself on to the most challenging and important conversations facing you."<ref name=page1-2>Scott et al., p. 1–2</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.projectconnections.com/knowhow/book_reviews_short/brs_fierce-conversations.html |title=Book review of "Fierce Conversations" |author= |date= |work=ProjectConnections |publisher=Emprend, Inc |accessdate=June 22, 2012}}</ref> The author states that the book is based on her experience running think tanks and designing and delivering training.<ref name=page1-2 /> The book was published by Viking in 2002 (hardcover version) and then by the [[Berkley Publishing Group]] in 2004 (paperback version). It has since become a [[Wall Street Journal]] and [[UPI]] bestseller.{{Citation needed|date=June 2012}}
==Fierce conversations== The author defines a fierce conversation as "One in which we come out from behind ourselves, into the conversation and make it real."<ref name=page7>Scott et al., p. 7</ref> She believes that interpersonal difficulties are a direct result of our inability to communicate well.<ref name=page7/>
Michael Brisciana has stated that "I worry that some of their most enthusiastic adherents can seem more eager for the 'fierce' (i.e., 'confrontational') part of the concept than the 'conversation'". Perhaps due to a misunderstanding of the book, they have the wrong kind of conversation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://hrperspectives.wordpress.com/2012/02/02/constructive-conversations-not-fierce-ones/#more-1171 |title=Constructive Conversations ... Not Fierce Ones |author=Michael Brisciana |date=June 20, 2012 |work=HR Perspectives |accessdate=June 22, 2012}}</ref>
==Contents==
* A foreword by [[Ken Blanchard]] * "The Seven Principles of Fierce Conversations" * "The Idea of Fierce" * "Master the Courage to Interrogate Reality" * "Come Out from Behind Yourself into the Conversation and Make It Real" * "Be Here, Prepared to Be Nowhere Else" * "Tackle Your Toughest Challenge Today" * "Obey Your Instincts" * "Take Responsibility for Your Emotional Wake" * "Let Silence Do the Heavy Lifting" * "Embracing the Principles"
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://www.fierceinc.com/conversations/ Fierce, Inc. Web site]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Fierce Conversations}} [[Category:2002 books]] [[Category:Business books]]

The '''Financial District''' is a [[highrise]] office area of within the central business district of [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]]'s [[Downtown Vancouver|downtown peninsula]]. Located roughly along [[Burrard Street|Burrard]] and [[Georgia Street|West Georgia Street]]s, the Financial District contains more than 60% of [[Greater Vancouver]]'s office space and is home to headquarter offices of forest products and mining companies. The area contains numerous federal and non-governmental organizations (NGO) offices, Overseas missions and consulates, and headquarter and branch offices of national and international banks and financial services, accounting and law firms, and luxury hotels.
==History==
The city's financial district emerged in the early 1900s when the building boom in the area began. From 1907 to 1913 a number of office buildings were built in the area along West Hastings Street:<ref>http://www.google.ca/search?hl=en&source=hp&q=Vancouver%27s+financial+district+emerged&meta=&aq=f&aqi=&aql=&oq=&gs_rfai=</ref>
* Sun Tower * Dominion Trust Building * Vancouver Stock Exchange
The financial district only expanded after the 1970s, with much of the new buildings emerging after the 1980s.
Vancouver's financial district is compact area when compared to other world cities. Most of the skyscrapers in the district are regional offices of the Big Five Canadian-based or International banks and various financial services institutions.
==Major skyscrapers and buildings== {{See also|Architecture of Vancouver}} {{colbegin|colwidth=22em}} * [[Trump International Hotel and Tower (Vancouver)]] * [[HSBC Canada Building]] * [[Harbour Centre]] * [[One Wall Centre]] * Guinness Tower * Burrard Building * [[Royal Centre (Vancouver)|Royal Centre]] * [[Park Place (Vancouver)|Park Place]] * [[MNP Tower]] * Canaccord Tower * [[Scotia Tower]] * Oceanic Plaza * [[Living Shangri-La]] * Cathedral Place * [[Fairmont Hotels and Resorts|Fairmont]] [[Hotel Vancouver]] * [[Ritz-Carlton Vancouver]] * FortisBC Centre * [[745 Thurlow]] * [[Western Forest Products]] * 1075 West Georgia Tower * [[Four Seasons Hotel Vancouver]] * [[Hyatt Regency Vancouver]] * [[Pacific Centre]] * [[Bentall Centre, Vancouver]] * [[Sinclair Centre]] * [[Sun Tower]] * [[Electra Building (Vancouver)|Electra Building]] * [[TD Tower (Vancouver)|TD Tower]] * [[Fairmont Pacific Rim]] {{colend}} ==Transit== Vancouver's Financial District is well served by numerous local and commuter bus routes running along [[Burrard Street|Burrard]] and [[Georgia Street|Georgia]] streets. In the heart of the Financial District lies [[Burrard Station]], providing [[rapid transit|metro]] rail access to thousands of commuters daily via [[SkyTrain (Vancouver)|SkyTrain]] [[Expo Line (TransLink)|Expo Line]]. A short distance to the north is [[Waterfront Station (Vancouver)|Waterfront Station]] which provides access to [[Seabus]], [[West Coast Express]] [[commuter rail]], and SkyTrain [[Canada Line]].

'''Gabriel Sandu''' (born September 8, 1963) is a [[Romania]]n economist and politician. A member of the [[Democratic Liberal Party (Romania)|Democratic Liberal Party]] (PD-L), he was a member of the [[Chamber of Deputies of Romania|Romanian Chamber of Deputies]] for [[Brăila County]] from 2004 to 2008. In the [[Emil Boc]] cabinet, he was [[Ministry of Communications and Information Society (Romania)|Minister of Communications and Information Society]] from 2008 to 2010, also serving as interim [[Ministry of Small and Medium Enterprises, Commerce and Business Environment (Romania)|Minister of Small and Medium Enterprises, Commerce and Business Environment]] in late 2009.
He has two sons and is divorced.<ref name="cvdeputat">{{ro icon}} [http://www.cdep.ro/pls/parlam/structura.mp?idm=101&cam=2&leg=2004&pag=0&idl=1 Profile at the Romanian Chamber of Deputies site]; retrieved May 23, 2009</ref><ref>{{ro icon}} Anca Răscutoi, [http://www.revista22.ro/guvernul-emil-boc-in-alb-si-negru-5284.html "Guvernul Emil Boc în alb şi negru" ("The Emil Boc Government in Black and White")], ''22'', 23 December 2008; retrieved May 23, 2009</ref>
==Biography==
He was born in [[Mizil]], [[Prahova County]]<ref name="cvdeputat"/> and after attending secondary school at the town's Grigore Tocilescu Theoretical High School, with a focus on mathematics and physics, enrolled at the [[Bucharest Academy of Economic Studies]]. He graduated in 1989 from the Commerce faculty. From 1990 to 1993 he headed the import-export division at a mattress factory in Mizil. From 1993 to 1997, he was vice president of a furniture producer and distributor in [[Bucharest]]. From 1997 to 2004, he was director of a private firm.<ref name="cvministru">{{ro icon}} [http://www.gov.ro/gabriel-sandu__l1a164.html Profile at the Romanian Government site]; retrieved May 23, 2009</ref>
After joining the [[Union of Right-Wing Forces]] (UFD), Sandu became the president of its Prahova County chapter in 1999. He was then vice president (2000-2001) and secretary general (2001-2003) of the party before its absorption into the [[National Liberal Party (Romania)|National Liberal Party]] (PNL). From 2003 to 2004, he was a supplementary member of the PNL's executive bureau and vice president of its Prahova County chapter. In November 2004, he was [[Romanian legislative election, 2004|elected]] to the Chamber, where he served on the Committee for Political Economy, Reform and Privatisation. From 2004 to 2006, he was part of the PNL's executive bureau and vice president of its Brăila County chapter.<ref name="cvministru"/> In December 2006, he resigned from the PNL to follow [[Theodor Stolojan]] into the new [[Liberal Democratic Party (Romania)|Liberal Democratic Party]] (PLD),<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.mediafax.ro/economic/bio-gabriel-sandu-un-economist-de-45-de-ani-la-comunicatii.html?1686;3669062 "Gabriel Sandu, un economist de 45 de ani la Comunicaţii" ("Gabriel Sandu: an Economist of 45 at Communications")]; Mediafax, 18 December 2008; retrieved May 23, 2009</ref> serving as that party's vice president for organisational consolidation and development. A year later, when the PLD merged into the PD-L, Sandu followed, and since then he has served as a vice president of the party and as first vice president of the Prahova County chapter.<ref name="cvministru"/>
At the [[Romanian legislative election, 2008|2008 election]], Sandu ran for a Prahova County [[Senate of Romania|Senate]] seat, but lost.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.alegeri.tv/alegeri-parlamentare-uninominale-2008/96/colegiu-uninominal-5-senat/prahova Election results], alegeri.tv; retrieved May 23, 2009</ref> During the campaign, two builders accused him of not paying 87,724 [[Romanian leu|lei]] (some [[United States dollar|$]]35,000) for two houses he ordered built in [[Sinaia]]; his name was also cited by an anti-money laundering agency regarding his dealings with an [[Italy|Italian]] company that was itself suspected of laundering.<ref>{{ro icon}} Olimpia Diaconiuc, [http://www.gardianul.ro/Deputatul-PD-L-Gabriel-Sandu,-acuzat-ca-da-tepe-in-afaceri-s125054.html "Deputatul PD-L Gabriel Sandu, acuzat ca da tepe in afaceri" ("PD-L Deputy Gabriel Sandu Accused of Deception in Dealings")], ''Gardianul'', 26 November 2008; retrieved May 23, 2009</ref> The following month, he was named minister in the incoming government.<ref name="regat">{{ro icon}} [http://www.adevarul.ro/articole/guvern-de-regateni-cu-mot-ardelean.html "Guvern de regăţeni, cu 'moţ' ardelean" ("Old Kingdom Government, with a Few Transylvanians")] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090522094314/http://www.adevarul.ro/articole/guvern-de-regateni-cu-mot-ardelean.html |date=May 22, 2009 }}, ''Adevărul'', 19 December 2008; retrieved May 23, 2009</ref> His priorities as minister include rapidly accessing [[European Union]] [[Structural Funds and Cohesion Funds|Structural Funds]], increasing interoperability among government agencies, developing the [[Information technology|IT]] and [[Broadband networks|broadband]] sectors, and [[digital television transition]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.9am.ro/stiri-revista-presei/Business/IT-C/120189/Ministrul-comunicatiilor-Scopul-nostru-este-sa-cheltuim-toate-fondurile-europene-anul-acesta.html "Ministrul comunicaţiilor: Scopul nostru este să cheltuim toate fondurile europene anul acesta" ("Minister of Communications: Our Goal Is to Spend All European Funds This Year")], NewsIn, 10 February 2009; retrieved May 23, 2009</ref> In October 2009, he became interim Small and Medium Enterprises Minister following the resignation of his PSD cabinet colleagues, including [[Constantin Niță]], the previous occupant of that ministry, holding the portfolio until December.<ref>{{ro icon}} Florina Zainescu, Lacrima Andreica and Adriana Duţulescu, [http://www.jurnalul.ro/stire-politic/guvernul-ingropat-cu-lautari-522702.html "Guvernul, îngropat cu lăutari" ("The Government, Interred with ''Lăutari''"], ''Jurnalul Naţional'', 2 October 2009; accessed July 23, 2010</ref><ref>{{ro icon}} [http://documentare.rompres.ro/guverne.php?i=120 Emil Boc II-III Government]; accessed September 4, 2010</ref> He was dismissed from the Communications Ministry in September 2010, following a cabinet reshuffle.<ref>{{ro icon}} Anca Simina, [http://www.evz.ro/detalii/stiri/pdl-istii-discuta-despre-depunerea-mandatului-de-boc-904914.html "S-a votat remanierea. Lista noilor miniştri" ("Reshuffle Approved. List of New Ministers")], ''Evenimentul Zilei'', 2 September 2010; accessed September 4, 2010</ref>
Sandu was implicated in the [[Microsoft licensing corruption scandal]], being charged with bribe-taking and money laundering. In March 2016, the [[High Court of Cassation and Justice]] sentenced him to two years' imprisonment and asset forfeiture of [[Euro|€]]2.2 million.<ref>{{ro icon}} Ionel Stoica, [http://adevarul.ro/news/eveniment/curtea-suprema-sentinta-dosarul-microsoft-pinalti-cocos-nicolae-sandu-recunoscut-acuzatiile-1_56f3956d5ab6550cb82b8d84/index.html "Sentinţe în dosarul 'Microsoft'" ("Sentences in the Microsoft Case")], ''Adevărul'', 24 March 2016; accessed March 25, 2016</ref> That October, the court increased his prison sentence to three years.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.mediafax.ro/social/dosarul-microsoft-in-pronuntare-gabriel-sandu-am-facut-denunt-la-departamenul-de-justitie-al-sua-video-15757850 "Condamnări definitive în Dosarul 'Microsoft'" ("Final Sentences in the Microsoft Case")], Mediafax, 3 October 2016; accessed October 3, 2016</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Infobox person |name = Gerardo Andrés Sofovich |image = Gerardo sofovich 1970.jpg |image_size = 200px |caption = Sofovich in 1970. |birth_date = {{birth date|1937|03|18}}{{cite news|language=Spanish|title=Murió Gerardo Sofovich|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1774446-murio-gerardo-sofovich|accessdate=8 March 2015|work=[[La Nación]]|date=8 March 2015}} |birth_place = [[Buenos Aires, Argentina]]{{cite news|title=Murió Gerardo Sofovich a los 77 años|url=http://www.radiobrisas.com/2015/03/08/murio-gerardo-sofovich-a-los-77-anos|accessdate=8 March 2015|language=Spanish|publisher=Radio Brisas|date=8 March 2015}} |death_date = {{death date and age|2015|3|8|1937|3|18}} |death_place = [[Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]] |partner = Carmen Morales (1965-1995)
Sofía Oleksak (2009-2011) |children = Gustavo Sofovich (n. 1968) |occupation = Businessman, dramaturge, television host, actor, comedian, scriptwriter and film director |relatives = [[Hugo Sofovich]] (brother) |parents = [[Manuel Sofovich]] (father)}} '''Gerardo Andrés Sofovich''' (March 18, 1937 – March 8, 2015) was an [[Argentina|Argentine]] [[businessman]], [[dramaturge]], [[Television presenter|television host and presenter]], [[comedian]], [[screenwriter|scriptwriter]], and [[film director|director]]. He was the producer of ''[[Polémica en el bar]]'' and ''La noche del Domingo'', two of the most popular Argentine TV shows of the 1970s and 1980s. Sofovich also hosted ''A la manera de Sofovich'' and ''Sin Límite SMS'', which were broadcast on [[Canal 9 (Argentina)|Canal 9]]. During the 1970s and 1980s he directed several [[picaresque]] films starring comedians [[Alberto Olmedo]] and [[Jorge Porcel]].As a businessman, he backed up major shows on [[Buenos Aires]]' Corrientes Avenue theaters. {{citation needed|date=March 2015}} His late brother [[Hugo Sofovich]] had a similar career as a film director and theater entrepreneur. Just before his death, he hosted another TV show, ''8 escalones'' (''8 steps''). {{citation needed|date=March 2015}} ==Health problems== Sofovich suffered a heart attack in 1992 at age 55. He had 15 stents put in and had twelve 12 angioplasties. On 8 October 2014, it was revealed that Sofovich had been connected to an artificial respirator and was sedated at [[Clinica Suizo-Argentina]] hospital after suffering a pulmonary infection, which complicated his health [[chronic obstructive pulmonary disease]] condition.{{cite news|title=Gerardo Sofovich está grave|url=http://www.ultimahora.com/gerardo-sofovich-esta-grave-n836613.html|accessdate=8 March 2015|work=[[Última Hora (Paraguay)|Última Hora]]|date=8 October 2014|language=Spanish}} He died on 8 March 2015, aged 77.{{cite news |title=Argentine TV legend Gerardo Sofovich dies |newspaper=[[Buenos Aires Herald]] |date={{Date|2015-3-8|mdy}} |url=http://www.buenosairesherald.com/article/183803/argentine-tv-legend-gerardo-sofovich-dies |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6WsW1NZeK?url=http://www.buenosairesherald.com/article/183803/argentine-tv-legend-gerardo-sofovich-dies |archivedate=8 March 2015 |language=Spanish |deadurl=yes |df= }} ==References== {{reflist|1}} ==External links== *{{IMDb name|0812176}} {{Bailando por un sueño (Argentina)}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sofovich, Gerardo}} [[Category:1937 births]] [[Category:2015 deaths]] [[Category:People from Buenos Aires]] [[Category:Argentine businesspeople]] [[Category:Argentine television personalities]] [[Category:Argentine Jews]] [[Category:Argentine people of Russian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Argentine film directors]] [[Category:Dramaturges]] [[Category:20th-century dramatists and playwrights]] {{Argentina-business-bio-stub}} {{Argentina-tv-bio-stub}}

{{nowrap|20457 [[Hamburg]], Germany}} | coords = {{coord|53|32|59|N|9|59|27|E|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | region_served = {{flag|Hamburg}} | services = | membership = 150,000 | membership_year = 2015 | language = German | owner = | sec_gen = | leader_title = President | leader_name = Tobias Bergmann | leader_title2 = {{nowrap|Chief Executive Officer}} | leader_name2 = Christi Degen | board_of_directors = | key_people = | main_organ = | subsidiaries = Commerzbibliothek
[[Hamburg School of Business Administration]] (HSBA) | affiliations = | budget = | budget_year = | revenue = | revenue_year = | disbursements = | expenses = | expenses_year = | endowment = | staff = 288 | staff_year = | website = {{official website|hk24.de}} | footnotes = }} [[File:Chamber of commerce Hamburg Germany.JPG|thumb|The chamber's main building (2006)]] [[File:Bundesarchiv B 145 Bild-F078953-0017, Hamburg, Börse.jpg|thumb|Floor of the [[Hamburg Stock Exchange]] (''Börse''), inside the Chamber of Commerce.]] The '''Hamburg Chamber of Commerce''' (''Handelskammer Hamburg''), originally named the '''Commercial Deputation''' (''Commerz-Deputation''), is the [[chamber of commerce]] for the city state of [[Hamburg]], and was founded in 1665. Hamburg has for centuries been a commercial centre of [[Northern Europe]], and the Hamburg Chamber of Commerce currently has 160,000 companies as its members. It was traditionally one of the three main political bodies of Hamburg. ==Role== The chamber has several official responsibilities. The [[Hamburg Stock Exchange]] (founded in 1558) is owned by and subordinate to the Hamburg Chamber of Commerce. The chamber has its offices in the old stock exchange building.Leitbild der Handelskammer Hamburg ''[http://www.hk24.de/servicemarken/ueber_uns/wir/Leitbild_Endversion_Handbuch.PDF www.hk24.de]'' (PDF) {{de icon}} The Commercial Deputation, founded in 1665, originally consisted of seven members, elected among the city's "honourable merchants." Each member became President of the Commercial Deputation during his last year in office. The Commercial Deputation was officially recognised by the Hamburg council (senate) in 1674 as the representation of the city's merchants. From 1710, all the seven members of the Commercial Deputation were also ''[[ex officio]]'' members of the ''Erbgesessene Bürgerschaft'' (the [[Hamburg Parliament]]). The Commercial Deputation was, along with council/senate and ''Bürgerschaft'', one of the most important political bodies of Hamburg. In 1735, the ''Commerzbibliothek'' (Library of Commerce) was founded, and is the oldest library of its kind. In 1867, the Commercial Deputation was transformed into the Hamburg Chamber of Commerce. Since 2004 the Chamber of Commerce organizes the bi-annual [[Hamburg Summit: China meets Europe]]. == Presidents of the Hamburg Commercial Deputation and Chamber of Commerce since 1665 == [[File:Ludwig Erdwin Seyler (1758-1836).jpg|thumb|[[Ludwig Erdwin Seyler]], an influential politician in Hamburg during the Napoleonic Wars who served as a member of the Commercial Deputation from {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2015}} {{Infobox newspaper | name = Handelsblatt | image = Logo Handelsblatt 2016.png | image_size = 250px | type = [[Daily newspaper]] | format = [[Compact (newspaper)|Compact]] | owners = Verlagsgruppe Handelsblatt | editor = [[Hans-Jürgen Jakobs]] | foundation = {{start date and age|df=y|1946|5|16}} | language = [[German language|German]] | headquarters = [[Düsseldorf]] | circulation = 127,546 (2018) | ISSN = 0017-7296 | website = [https://www.handelsblatt.com/ www.handelsblatt.com] }} [[File:Handelsblatt-1.jpg|thumbnail]] The '''''Handelsblatt''''' (literally "commerce paper" in English) is a leading [[German language|German-language]] business newspaper published in [[Düsseldorf]] by Verlagsgruppe Handelsblatt.
==History and profile== ''Handelsblatt'' was established in 1946.<ref>{{cite web|author=Carsten Croonenbroeck|author2=Roman Matkovskyy|title=Is the Market Held by Institutional Investors? The Disposition Effect Revisited.|url=http://www.wiwi.europa-uni.de/de/forschung/publikationen-projekte/dp/_dokumente/338_Croonenbroeck_Matkovskyy.pdf|work=European University Viadrina Frankfurt|accessdate=3 February 2015|format=Discussion paper. No: 338|date=July 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|editor=Robert G. Picard|title=Media Firms: Structures, Operations, and Performance|date=2002|publisher=Lawrence Erlbaum Associates|location=Mahwah, NJ|page=61|url=https://www.questia.com/read/104790656/media-firms-structures-operations-and-performance|accessdate=26 December 2014}}{{Subscription required|via=Questia}}</ref> Its [[editor-in-chief]] (since January 2013) is Hans-Jürgen Jakobs.<ref>[//www.horizont.net/aktuell/leute/pages/protected/Gabor-Steingart-wird-Geschaeftsfuehrer-der-Verlagsgruppe-Handelsblatt_110987.html''Gabor Steingart new CEO of Verlagsgruppe Handelsblatt'']. Horizont.net, 4 November 2012.</ref> Its publisher, Verlagsgruppe Handelsblatt, also publishes the weekly business magazine ''[[Wirtschaftswoche]]''<ref>{{cite news|title=Handelsblatt and WiWo continue to lead the German market|url=http://www.advance.uk.com/news|accessdate=3 February 2015|work=Advance Media|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150203083524/http://www.advance.uk.com/news|archivedate=3 February 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> of which the editor-in-chief is [[Miriam Meckel]] since 2014. ''Handelsblatt'''s headquarters are in Düsseldorf.<ref>{{cite web|title=German Online Newspapers and Magazines|url=http://aic.almania.info/german-newspapers.htm|work=Almania Information Center|accessdate=28 March 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150102102836/http://aic.almania.info/german-newspapers.htm|archivedate=2 January 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Since September 2005 ''Handelsblatt'' has been offering an online lexicon called ''WirtschaftsWiki''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.handelsblatt.com/wirtschaftswiki/|title=Wirtschaftslexikon|work=Handelsblatt|accessdate=3 February 2015}}</ref> which features definitions of terms used in economics and politics. The database can be modified by any registered user.
In September 2006 ''Handelsblatt'' ranked all economists working in Germany, Austria and the German-speaking part of Switzerland.<ref>[https://www.handelsblatt.com/news/default_302031_1170092.aspx "English summary"] of the ranking</ref> The paper is published in [[Compact (newspaper)|compact format]].<ref>{{cite web|title=References|url=http://tolerans.com/9/page.asp?page_id=8983&type=display|work=Tolerans|accessdate=5 February 2015}}</ref>
In 2009, [[Dieter von Holtzbrinck]] bought ''Der Tagesspiegel'', ''Handelsblatt'' and "WirtschaftsWoche" from the [[Georg von Holtzbrinck Publishing Group]].
In 2014, ''Handelsblatt'' launched a digital, English-language edition, called ''Handelsblatt Global Edition'', which aims to reach an international audience interested in German business and finance news. The editor-in-chief is Andreas Kluth. The ''Global Edition'' is published five days a week from its editorial office in Berlin.<ref>{{cite web|title="Handelsblatt" bringt englischsprachige Ausgabe an den Start|url=http://www.focus.de/regional/duesseldorf/medien-handelsblatt-bringt-englischsprachige-ausgabe-an-den-start_id_4208399.html|website=Focus Online|publisher=Hubert Burda Media|accessdate=7 July 2015}}</ref>
''Handelsblatt'' had a circulation of 127,546 daily copies in 2018.<ref name="IVW">[http://www.ivw.eu/ IVW - Informationsgemeinschaft zur Feststellung der Verbreitung von Werbeträgern e.V] </ref>
