{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox person |name = Sergio Marchionne |image = Fiat Sergio Marchionne (cropped).jpg |image_size = 200px |caption = Marchionne in 2007 |birth_date = June 17, 1952 |birth_place = [[Chieti]], Italy |death_date = {{death date and age|2018|7|25|1952|6|17}} |death_place = [[Zurich]], Switzerland |alma_mater = [[University of Toronto]]
[[University of Windsor]]
[[Osgoode Hall Law School]] |occupation= {{nowrap|Former Chairman of [[CNH Industrial]]
Former CEO of [[Ferrari]]
Former CEO of [[Fiat Chrysler Automobiles]]
Former Chairman of [[Maserati]]
Former CEO of [[FCA Italy]]
Former CEO of [[Chrysler|FCA US]]
Former Chairman of [[SGS S.A.|SGS]]}} |spouse = Orlandina ({{abbr|div.|divorced}}){{cite web|url=https://www.today.it/donna/trend/sergio-marchionne-compagna-manuela-battezzato-chi-e.html |title=Sergio Marchionne, la compagna Manuela sempre al suo fianco |publisher=Today.it |date=October 20, 2017 |accessdate=July 25, 2018}} |partner = Manuela Battezzato[https://www.letteradonna.it/it/articoli/ritratti/2018/07/23/manuela-battezzato-marchionne-moglie-orlandina/26251/ Chi è Manuela Battezzato, la compagna di Sergio Marchionne]{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/07/25/the-associated-press-sergio-marchionne-who-saved-fiat-and-chrysler-has-died.html |title=Sergio Marchionne, who saved Fiat and Chrysler, has died |publisher=Cnbc.com |date=March 30, 2015 |accessdate=July 25, 2018}} |children = 2 sons }} '''Sergio Marchionne''' ({{IPA-it|ˈsɛrdʒo marˈkjɔnne|lang}}; June 17, 1952 – July 25, 2018) was an Italian-Canadian businessman, widely known for his turnarounds of the automakers [[Fiat]] and [[Chrysler]], his business acumen and his outspoken and often frank approach, especially when dealing with unpalatable issues related to his companies and the automotive industry. Marchionne was the chairman of [[CNH Industrial]], the chief executive officer (CEO) of [[Fiat Chrysler Automobiles]], the chairman and CEO of [[Chrysler|FCA US LLC]], the chairman and CEO of [[Ferrari]], and the chairman of [[Maserati]]. He was the chairman of Swiss-based [[SGS S.A.|SGS]] and vice chairman of [[UBS]] from 2008 to 2010, as well as the chairman of the [[European Automobile Manufacturers Association]] for 2012 (first elected in January 2006).{{cite web|url=http://www.automotiveworld.com/WVMA/content.asp?contentid=57460 |title=Europe: Sergio Marchionne re-elected president of ACEA |publisher=Automotive World |date=January 12, 2007 |accessdate=September 1, 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/02/21/business/ubs.php|title=UBS Plans to Cut Chairman's Next Term After Subprime Losses.|publisher=International Herald Tribune|accessdate=February 27, 2008}} He was a member of the [[Peterson Institute for International Economics]], and the chairman of the Italian branch of the [[Council for the United States and Italy]]. Noted for his keen observations of the automotive industry, Marchionne's insights ranged from frank criticism of his company's own products to a highly-regarded 2015 presentation titled ''Confessions of a Capital Junkie,'' extolling the benefits of industry consolidation.{{cite web | title = Fiat CEO’s merger confession called ‘spot on’ | publisher = The Wall Street Journal | author = Tommaso Ebhardt | date = May 26, 2015 | url = https://www.wsj.com/public/article_print/SB110194232087888545.html}} Marchionne was widely recognized for turning around [[FCA Italy|Fiat Group]] to become one of the fastest growing companies in the [[automotive industry|auto industry]],{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/autos/autobeat/archives/2007/01/fiat_on_a_roll.html|title=Fiat Burning Rubber|publisher=BusinessWeek|accessdate=May 17, 2007}} in less than two years.{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/16806317|title=Fiat Net Profit Soars as Automaker Promises the First Dividend Since 2002|publisher=MSNBC.com|accessdate=May 17, 2007}} In 2009, he was instrumental in Fiat Group forming a strategic alliance with the ailing US automaker [[Chrysler]], with the support of the U.S. and Canadian governments and trade unions. Less than two years later, following its emergence from Chapter 11, Chrysler returned to profitability, repaying all government loans. In 2014, Fiat and Chrysler merged into a new holding company, [[Fiat Chrysler Automobiles]], now the seventh-largest automobile manufacturer in the world.{{Cite news|title = Fiat Chrysler to spin off Ferrari, issue $2.5 billion convertible bond|url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/10/29/us-fiatchrysler-ferrari-divestiture-idUSKBN0II1DB20141029|newspaper = Reuters|date = October 29, 2014|access-date = July 11, 2015}} Following complications from surgery, Marchionne resigned from all of his positions in July 2018{{cite news | authorlink = | author1 = Jackie Wattles | author2 = Chris Isidore | author3 = Peter Valdes-Dapena | title = Sergio Marchionne, auto legend, steps down as CEO of Fiat Chrysler | url = https://money.cnn.com/2018/07/21/news/companies/sergio-marchionne-fiat-chrysler-stepping-down/index.html | work = | publisher = CNN | date = July 21, 2018 | accessdate = July 22, 2018 | quote = }} and died a few days later.{{cite news |title=Zurigo, morto a 66 anni Sergio Marchionne – Tgcom24 |url=http://www.tgcom24.mediaset.it/economia/zurigo-morto-a-66-anni-sergio-marchionne_3154131-201802a.shtml |accessdate=July 25, 2018 |work=Tgcom24 |language=Italian}} The American business channel [[CNBC]] described Marchionne as a "legend of [[automotive industry]]",{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/07/25/fiat-chrysler-sergio-marchionne-dies.html |title=Auto industry legend CEO Sergio Marchionne dies at age 66 |publisher=Cnbc.com |date=October 1, 2009 |accessdate=July 25, 2018}} while the British newspaper ''[[Financial Times]]'' considered him as having been "one of the boldest business leaders of his generation".{{cite web|url=https://ft.trib.al/IYK02rG |title=Sergio Marchionne, car company executive, 1952-2018 |publisher=Ft.trib.al|date= |accessdate=July 25, 2018}} ==Early life== Marchionne was born in [[Chieti]], [[Abruzzo]], Italy,{{cite web |url=http://fiatspa.com/en-US/governance/management/FiatDocuments/cv/Marchionne%20Sergio_CV_GEC_02-01-2012_eng.pdf |title="Marchionne Sergio CV" (PDF). Fiat Group. Retrieved January 2, 2012. |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=September 1, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120717005506/http://www.fiatspa.com/en-US/governance/management/FiatDocuments/cv/Marchionne%20Sergio_CV_GEC_02-01-2012_eng.pdf |archivedate=July 17, 2012 |df= }} the son of Concezio Marchionne, from [[Cugnoli]] (Abruzzo), and Maria Zuccon from Carnizza (today [[Krnica, Marčana|Krnica]], [[Croatia]]) near [[Labin]] in [[Istria]]. His father served as a ''[[Carabiniere]]'' in Istria, where he met his future wife. Marchionne's grandfather, Giacomo Zuccon, was killed in September 1943 by [[Yugoslav Partisans]] near [[Barban]] in Istria, while his uncle Giuseppe Zuccon was killed by the Nazis the same year. In 1945, when the region was occupied by the Yugoslav army, Marchionne's parents moved to [[Chieti]] in Abruzzo, where Sergio was born.{{cite web|url=http://www.secoloditalia.it/2018/07/marchionne-il-nonno-infoibato-listria-nel-sangue-il-dramma-di-una-famiglia-italiana/ |title=Marchionne, il nonno infoibato, l’Istria nel sangue: il dramma di una famiglia italiana |publisher=Secoloditalia.it |date=February 23, 1976 |accessdate=July 25, 2018}} At 13, Marchionne emigrated with his family to [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada, where they had relatives.{{cite web|url=http://www.abruzzoemigrazione.it/e_view.asp?E=44|title=Emigrazione Abruzzese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722023047/http://www.abruzzoemigrazione.it/e_view.asp?E=44|archivedate=July 22, 2011}} Carrying dual Canadian and Italian citizenship, he spoke fluent English, French and Italian. Marchionne was a Canadian [[Chartered Professional Accountant|certified general accountant]] (FCGA),{{cite web|url=http://www.cga-canada.org/en-ca/Programs/ScholarshipsAwardsAndOpportunities/HonoursAndAwards/FellowshipAward/Pages/ca_members_hon_awards_fcga_recipients.aspx |title=2011 CGA Fellowship Recipients |publisher=Cga-canada.org |date=December 12, 2011 |accessdate=September 1, 2012}} [[barrister]], and a fellow of the [[Certified General Accountants of Ontario]].[https://www.webeconomia.it/sergio-marchionne-ecco-chi-lo-sostituira-in-fca/17356/ Sergio Marchionne: ecco chi lo sostituirà in FCA] Marchionne attended [[St. Michael's College School]], before completing his undergraduate studies in philosophy at the [[University of Toronto]] and earning a bachelor of commerce degree (1979) and an MBA (1985) from the [[University of Windsor]]{{cite web|url=http://www.uwindsor.ca/alumni/sergio-marchionne-bcomm-79-mba-85|title=Sergio Marchionne BComm '79, MBA '85, Alumni Association, University of Windsor}} as well as a law degree from [[Osgoode Hall Law School]] of [[York University]] (1983).{{cite web|url=http://www.yorku.ca/yfile/archive/index.asp?Article=2903|title=York in the Media|publisher=Y-File|accessdate=May 17, 2007}} He received an honorary doctorate from [[Walsh College]] (2013).{{cite web|url=https://www.fcagroup.com/en-US/group/governance/board_of_directors/Pages/sergio_marchionne.aspx|title=Sergio Marchionne|publisher=www.fcagroup.com|accessdate=August 9, 2017}} ==Career== [[File:Marcchionne.png|thumb|right|Sergio Marchionne in 2006]] From 1983 to 1985, he worked as an accountant and tax specialist for [[Deloitte & Touche]] in Canada. From 1985 to 1988, he was Group Controller and then Director of Corporate Development at the Lawson Mardon Group in Toronto. In 1989, he moved to Glenex Industries where he worked for two years as Executive Vice President.[https://www.linkiesta.it/it/article/2018/07/22/sergio-marchionne-il-duro-in-pullover-che-ha-rivoluzionato-la-fiat/38905/ Sergio Marchionne, il duro in pullover che ha rivoluzionato la Fiat] From 1990 to 1992, he was Vice President of Finance and Chief Financial Officer at Acklands Ltd. Between 1992 and 1994, he served as Vice President of Legal and Corporate Development and Chief Financial Officer of the Lawson Group, which was acquired by [[Alusuisse-Lonza Holding|Alusuisse Lonza]] (Algroup) in 1994.{{cite web|url=https://www.ilfoglio.it/economia/2018/07/21/news/sergio-marchionne-978/ |title=Sergio Marchionne – Il Foglio |publisher=Ilfoglio.it |date=July 21, 2018 |accessdate=July 25, 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.autocar.co.uk/slideshow/sergio-marchionne-obituary-great-life-pictures|title=Sergio Marchionne obituary: a great life, in pictures|website=www.autocar.co.uk|language=en|access-date=July 25, 2018}} From 1994 to 2000, he worked at Algroup (Alusuisse Lonza Group Limited) based in Zurich, where he became Chief Executive Officer in 1997. He then took the helm of the [[Lonza Group]] in Basel, after its spin-off from Algroup, serving first as Chief Executive Officer and Managing Director (2000–2001) and then as Chairman (2002).{{cite web|author=Adnkronos |url=https://notizie.tiscali.it/economia/articoli/marchionne-destino-europa-america-00001/ |title=Marchionne, un destino fra Europa e America |publisher=Notizie.tiscali.it |date= |accessdate=July 25, 2018}} In February 2002, he became Chief Executive Officer and Managing Director of [[Société Générale de Surveillance|SGS S.A.]] of Geneva where, in March 2006, he was appointed Chairman. Marchionne was elected as an independent member of the Board of Directors of Fiat S.p.A. in May 2003, until being appointed CEO in 2004.{{cite web|last=July |first=Bloomberg |url=http://fortune.com/2018/07/21/sergio-marchionne-fiat-chrysler/ |title=A Timeline of Sergio Marchionne's Transformative Fiat Chrysler Tenure |publisher=Fortune.com |date=July 21, 2018 |accessdate=July 25, 2018}} ===Chrysler=== [[File:Secretary Geithner Visits Detroit (5669161307).jpg|thumb|Chrysler Group CEO Sergio Marchionne (left-right), Congressman [[Hansen Clarke]] (MI-13), Plant Manager Pat Walsh, Secretary [[Tim Geithner]], and [[UAW]] President [[Bob King (labor leader)|Bob King]] on a tour of [[Jefferson North Assembly Plant]] (JNAP) in [[Detroit]], on April 2011|alt=]] In June 2009, when [[Chrysler]] emerged from [[Chapter 11 bankruptcy]] protection, Fiat Group received a 20% stake in Chrysler Group LLC and Marchionne was appointed CEO, replacing existing CEO [[Robert Nardelli]].{{cite web|author= Noah Joseph RSS feed |url=http://www.autoblog.com/2009/05/07/breaking-marchionne-confirmed-as-post-bankruptcy-chrysler-ceo/ |title=BREAKING: Marchionne confirmed as post-bankruptcy Chrysler CEO |publisher=Autoblog.com |date= |accessdate=September 1, 2012}} In February 2011 Marchionne sparked widespread controversy in the U.S. when he remarked at the [[J.D. Power & Associates]] International Automotive Roundtable that Chrysler's [[Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008|bail-out loans]] from the U.S. government carried "[[shyster]] rates".{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/2515333e-321d-11e0-a820-00144feabdc0.html|title=Fiat in firestorm for floating Detroit move|author=Rachel Sanderson and John Reed|date=February 6, 2011|newspaper=Financial Times|accessdate=February 7, 2011}} Marchionne immediately issued a public apology, stating "I regret the remark and consider it inappropriate" and going on to explain that "As the only parties willing to underwrite the risk associated with Chrysler’s recovery plan, the two governments [U.S. and Canadian] levied interest rates that, although appropriate at the time, are above current market conditions."{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-05/chrysler-s-marchionne-says-he-regrets-loans-comment-update1-.html|title=Chrysler's Marchionne Says Calling Loans `Shyster Rates' Was Inappropriate|author=Dan Hart|date=February 5, 2011|newspaper=Bloomberg News|accessdate=February 7, 2011}} In July 2011, following the purchase of the ownership interests held by Canada and the US Treasury, Fiat’s stake in Chrysler increased to 53.5% and in September 2011, Marchionne was also elected Chairman of Chrysler. Fiat and Chrysler officially merged under Marchionne's leadership on August 1, 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.fcagroup.com/en-US/media_center/FiatDocuments/2014/Agosto/Approval_of_Cross_Border_Merger.pdf?redirectFromFiatspa=1|title=APPROVAL OF CROSS-BORDER MERGER TO CREATE FIAT CHRYSLER AUTOMOBILES N.V. (FCA)|website=www.fcagroup.com|publisher=Fiat S.p.A.|accessdate=September 20, 2015}} Following the 2015 [[Volkswagen emissions scandal]], in January 2017, the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|EPA]] also accused Fiat Chrysler of illegally installing [[Defeat device#2010s|software that allowed excess diesel emissions to go undetected]]. Marchionne denied any wrongdoing. Therein he was critical of the EPA and rejected comparisons between Fiat Chrysler and [[Volkswagen]].{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-fiatchrysler-emissions-idUSKBN14W29S|title=EPA accuses Fiat Chrysler of excess diesel emissions|author1=David Shepardson|author2=Bernie Woodall|date=January 13, 2017|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=March 7, 2017}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/12/business/epa-emissions-cheating-diesel-fiat-chrysler-jeep-dodge.html|title=E.P.A. Accuses Fiat Chrysler of Secretly Violating Emissions Standards|author1=Hiroko Tabuchi|date=January 12, 2017|accessdate=March 7, 2017|publisher=The New York Times}}{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/cars/2017/01/12/fiat-chrysler-automobiles-epa-environmental-protection-agency/96485486/|title=EPA accuses Fiat Chrysler of cheating emissions laws|author1=Nathan Bomey|date=January 12, 2017|publisher=USA today|accessdate=March 7, 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/business/2017/01/12/fiat-chrysler-accused-of-emission-cheating-by-us-report.html|title=Fiat Chrysler accused of emission cheating by U.S.|author1=Tom Krisher|author2=Michael Biesecker|date=January 12, 2017|publisher=The Toronto Star|accessdate=March 7, 2017}} ==Death== Marchionne last appeared in public on June 26, 2018 in Rome, presenting a Jeep to the Carabinieri, Italy’s military police.[http://www.autonews.com/article/20180721/OEM02/180729913 'FCA paints grim picture of Marchionne's health,'] [[Autonews]], July 21, 2018. FCA subsequently announced Marchionne had taken medical leave for shoulder surgery at the [[University Hospital of Zürich]] in Switzerland — adding on the day of surgery he would not return due to post-surgical complications.{{cite web|url=http://www.autonews.com/article/20180721/OEM02/180729913/sergio-marchionne-health-fiat-chrysler-fca|title=Fiat Chrysler Paints Grim Picture of Marchionne's Health|publisher=|accessdate=July 23, 2018}} After further serious complications,{{cite web|url=https://www.freep.com/story/money/cars/chrysler/2018/07/25/sergio-marchionne-embolism-surgery/837084002/|title=Sergio Marchionne had embolism during surgery.|date=July 25, 2018|publisher=[[Detroit Free Press]]}} on July 21, 2018, Marchionne was replaced at FCA, Ferrari, SGS and CNH.{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-07-21/fiat-is-said-to-name-jeep-chief-manley-to-replace-ceo-marchionne|title=Fiat Names Jeep Chief Manley to Replace CEO Marchionne|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/fiatchrysler-ceo/fiat-ferrari-boards-to-meet-on-marchionne-succession-report-idUSL8N1UH03E|title=Fiat, Ferrari boards to meet on Marchionne succession – report|first=Reuters|last=Editorial|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-fiatchrysler-ceo-manley/fiat-chrysler-to-name-jeeps-manley-to-replace-marchionne-as-ceo-source-idUKKBN1KB0MF|title=Fiat Chrysler to name Jeep's Manley to replace Marchionne as CEO -...|first=Reuters|last=Editorial|publisher=}} He died on July 25, 2018, at age 66,{{cite web|author=Di Paolo Griseri |url=http://www.repubblica.it/economia/2018/07/25/news/e_morto_sergio_marchionne-202614191/?ref=RHPPTP-BH-I0-C12-P1-S1.12-T1 |title=E' morto Sergio Marchionne, l'uomo che salvò l'auto italiana |publisher=Repubblica.it |date= |accessdate=July 25, 2018}} survived by his partner Manuela Battezzato, his two adult sons, Alessio and Tyler, and former wife Orlandina.{{cite web|author=Bianca Carretto |url=https://www.corriere.it/cronache/18_luglio_25/marchionne-compagna-manuela-la-mia-fortuna-figli-l-amore-l-italia-volto-segreto-manager-df3eee68-8ff2-11e8-9e3d-9a7bf81b9c8e.shtml |title=Marchionne: la compagna Manuela Battezzato, i figli, l'Italia. Il suo volto segreto |publisher=Corriere.it |date= |accessdate=July 25, 2018}} ==Public image== [[File:SERGIO MARCHIONNE.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Marchionne wearing his classic black woolen sweater]] Marchionne earned a reputation for an outspoken and often blunt approach.{{cite web|url=http://business.financialpost.com/news/transportation/fiat-chrysler-automobiles-ceo-has-nothing-to-fear-from-the-ontario-government|title=Sergio Marchionne has nothing to fear from the Ontario government|author1=Kristine Owram|date=July 14, 2015|publisher=Financial Post|accessdate=March 7, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/the-new-iacocca-chrysler-ceo-marchionne-is-already-sorry-he-opened-his-mouth/|title=The New Iacocca: Chrysler CEO Marchionne Is Already Sorry He Opened His Mouth|date=February 7, 2011|publisher=CBS News|accessdate=March 7, 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/business/2014/03/07/chrysler_chief_sergio_marchionne_straight_shooter_tough_negotiator.html|title=Chrysler chief Sergio Marchionne: straight shooter, tough negotiator|author1=Dana Flavelle|date=March 7, 2014|publisher=The Toronto Star|accessdate=March 7, 2017}} In a 2009 ''[[Forbes]]'' interview, Massimo Vecchio, an analyst with [[Mediobanca]], commented on the contrast and Marchionne's controversial management style:{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/2009/04/14/fiat-chrysler-marchionne-markets-equity-auto.html|title=Can Sergio Marchionne Save Chrysler?|author1=Javier Espinoza|date=April 14, 2009|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=March 7, 2017}}{{Quote|text="He's got a lot of American in his management style. The only thing that matters to him is results. If you don't deliver, you are out. He is quite ruthless. When Marchionne took over the company [Fiat], he was literally firing one manager a day but there was a leadership problem and nobody wanted to take hard decisions. The communication from bottom to top in management was slow and wrong. He also changed that. He reduced the layers of management and gave his role a more direct view of what the business was doing. And of course his ego is very big and sometimes people who had clashes with him were basically fired. Looking at his style from outside it seems awful, but he delivered."}} Despite the buttoned-down business world in which he worked, Marchionne disliked having to think about his wardrobe, and became known for wearing black sweaters and jeans — keeping a supply of both in each of his residences.{{cite web |title = Sergio Marchionne, Who Revived Fiat and Chrysler, Dies at 66 |publisher = The New York Times |author = Neal E. Boudette and Elisabetta Povoledo |date = July 25, 2018 |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/25/business/sergio-marchionne-dies-fiat-chrysler.html?hpw&rref=business&action=click&pgtype=Homepage&module=well-region®ion=bottom-well&WT.nav=bottom-well}}{{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/business/2011/11/22/why_chrysler_boss_sergio_marchionne_always_wears_black.html|title=Why Chrysler boss Sergio Marchionne always wears black – The Star|publisher=}} Reporters noted that he had not been seen wearing a [[necktie]] since 2007.{{cite web|url=https://eu.freep.com/story/money/cars/2018/06/01/sergio-marchionne-tie-fca/662913002/|title=FCA CEO Sergio Marchionne surprises audience with this fashion choice|publisher=}} He was a [[chain-smoker]] until his final months.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/21/business/fiat-chrysler-ceo.html |title=Fiat Chrysler C.E.O. Marchionne Is Replaced After Falling Gravely Ill |publisher=The New York Times |author1=Neal E. Boudette |date=July 21, 2018 }} ==Honors and awards== * [[File:Cavaliere OML BAR.svg|80px]] [[Order of Merit for Labour|Cavaliere del Lavoro]] – June 1, 2006{{cite web|url=http://www.quirinale.it/elementi/DettaglioOnorificenze.aspx?decorato=165283 |title=Sito web del Quirinale: dettaglio decorato |publisher=Quirinale.it |date= |accessdate=September 1, 2012}} *2005, Honorary Doctor of Laws from the University of Windsor (Canada){{Cite news|url=http://canada.autonews.com/article/20180722/CANADA01/307229993/illness-ends-career-of-sergio-marchionne-the-ceo-who-liked-to-fix|title=Illness ends career of Sergio Marchionne, the CEO who liked to fix things|last=Flak|first=Agnieszka|date=July 22, 2018|work=Automotive News Canada|access-date=July 22, 2018|last2=Barbaglia|first2=Pamela}} *2007, Masters honoris causa from the CUOA Foundation (Italy){{cite web|url=https://www.quiminet.com/articulos/biografia-de-sergio-marchionne-el-ceo-que-revivio-a-fiat-chrysler-y-que-convirtio-a-ferrari-en-la-cuarta-marca-mas-poderosa-del-mundo-4256854.htm|title=Biografía de Sergio Marchionne, el CEO que revivió a Fiat, Chrysler y que convirtió a Ferrari en la cuarta Marca Más Poderosa del Mundo {{!}} QuimiNet.com|last=Marketizer.com|first=QuimiNet.com / e-Industria.com /|website=www.quiminet.com|language=es|access-date=July 25, 2018}} *2007, Degree in Economics honoris causa from the Università degli Studi di Cassino{{Cite news|url=https://www.panorama.it/news/cronaca/la-biografia-sergio-marchionne-uomo-maglione-che-ha-cambiato-la-fiat/|title=Sergio Marchionne, il manager in maglione che ha cambiato la Fiat - Panorama|last=Degl'Innocenti|first=Chiara|date=July 25, 2018|work=Panorama|access-date=July 25, 2018|language=it-IT}} *2008, he received a degree ad honorem in Industrial Engineering and Management from [[Polytechnic University of Turin]] (Italy){{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} *Honorary Doctor of Business Administration from the University of Toledo (Ohio), May 8, 2011{{Cite news|url=http://apps.npr.org/commencement/speech/sergio-marchionne-university-of-toledo-2011/|title=Sergio Marchionne, 2011|work=NPR.org|access-date=July 25, 2018|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://msutoday.msu.edu/news/2013/msu-announces-fall-commencement-speakers/|title=MSU announces fall commencement speakers|last=University|first=Michigan State|work=MSUToday|access-date=July 25, 2018|language=en}} *2010, Marchionne was awarded the Premio Pico della Mirandola.{{cite web|url=http://corrieredibologna.corriere.it/bologna/notizie/economia/2010/5-novembre-2010/monetine-contro-marchionne-contro-premio-lavoratori-1804102940270.shtml |title=Marchionne viene contestato per aver ricevuto il premio Pico 2010 |publisher=Corrieredibologna.corriere.it |date= |accessdate=September 1, 2012}} *2011, Marchionne was awarded [[The Deming Cup]] 2011 for operational excellence presented by W. Edwards Deming Center at [[Columbia Business School]].{{cite web|url=http://media.chrysler.com/newsrelease.do?id=11712&mid=2|title=Chrysler Group Chairman and CEO Sergio Marchionne Awarded Deming Cup by Columbia Business School|publisher=Fiat Chrysler Automobiles|date=November 4, 2011|accessdate=March 7, 2017}} *2011, The [[Business Council for International Understanding]] honored Marchionne with the Dwight D. Eisenhower Leadership Award{{cite web|title=Chrysler Group Chairman and CEO Sergio Marchionne Awarded Global Leadership Award by Business Council for International Understanding |url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/chrysler-group-chairman-and-ceo-sergio-marchionne-awarded-global-leadership-award-by-business-council-for-international-understanding-135086163.html}}{{cite web |title = BCIU Gala |url = http://bciu.org/wip05/public/gala.asp |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120624122031/http://bciu.org/wip05/public/gala.asp |archivedate = June 24, 2012 |df = }} *2015, Marchionne was awarded the Hennick Medal for Career Achievement at Osgoode Hall Law School, York University by The Hennick Centre for Business and Law.{{cite web|url=https://hennickcentre.ca/people/career-medal-recipients/|title=Hennick Medal for Career Achievement : Hennick Centre|website=hennickcentre.ca|language=en-US|access-date=July 25, 2018}} * 2015, http://saefoundation.org/News-Events/Events/Celebration/Awards|title= SAE Foundation Industry Leadership Award.|access-date= Jul 27, 2018|language= en|archive-url= |archive-date= |deadurl= no}}.{{cite Leadership Awardee.|last=|first=|date=Oct 21, 2014|work=Automotive World|access-date=July 24, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180724234427/https://www.automotiveworld.com/news-releases/fcas-marchionne-named-sae-foundation%C2%80%C2%99s-2015-industry-leadership-awardee/|archive-date=July 23, 2018|deadurl=no|place=Detroit, Michigan|language=en}} The award of 2016 has been recognized to [[Mark Fields (businessman)|Mark Fields]], Chief Executive Officer of Ford Motor Company{{cite {{Infobox person | name = Tareq Al-Suwaidan [[M.Sc.]], [[Ph.D.]] | image = Tareq Al-Suwaidan.jpg | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Kuwait]] | nationality = [[Kuwait]] | occupation = Chairman of Gulf Innovation Group | education = [[Penn State University]]
[[University of Tulsa]] | title = | television = [[General manager]] of [[Al-Resalah TV]] (2006-2013) | website = [http://www.suwaidan.com www.suwaidan.com] }} '''Tareq Mohammed Al-Suwaidan''' ({{lang-ar|طارق محمد السويدان}}) is a [[Kuwait]]i [[writer]], [[historian]], [[businessman]], and Muslim scholar, He is [[Chairman]] of "Innovation Group". He is well known in the [[Middle East]] and in Muslim communities throughout the world for his [[management]]/[[strategic planning]] training, and [[television]] shows and appearances. According to ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine (Arabic edition: Forbes Arabia), Al-Suwaidan ranks second in annual net income among Islamic speakers in the Muslim world with an estimated net profit of $1 million in 2007.http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2008/02/28/46255.html Al-Suwaidan was trained in the classical Islamic sciences in his youth and lived and studied in the [[United States]] from the age of 17 and remained for 20 years, graduating from high school, and receiving a [[B.S.]] in petroleum and natural gas engineering from [[Penn State University]] in 1975 and an [[M.Sc.]] and [[Ph.D.]] in 1990 in [[petroleum engineering]] from the [[University of Tulsa]].{{cite web|url=http://en.zl50.com/20130409369374908.html|title=zl50.com|website=en.zl50.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thedohadebates.com/output/Page29.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2005-11-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051127101957/http://www.thedohadebates.com/output/Page29.asp |archivedate=2005-11-27 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.memri.org/report/en/0/0/0/0/0/0/6453.htm|title=Kuwaiti Muslim Brotherhood Leader And Director Of Saudi Al-Risala TV Tareq Al-Suwaidan Tours West, Promoting Restoration Of Caliphate And New Era Of Cyber Jihad|work=MEMRI - The Middle East Media Research Institute}} Al-Suwaidan has preached to large audiences in the U.K. Canada, and Australia. He has spoken to Western audiences at venues such as Georgetown University School of Foreign Service in Qatar. He frequently supports Western and American Muslim organizations. {{cite web|url=http://www.memri.org/report/en/print6453.htm|title=Kuwaiti Muslim Brotherhood Leader And Director Of Saudi Al-Risala TV Tareq Al-Suwaidan Tours West, Promoting Restoration Of Caliphate And New Era Of Cyber Jihad|publisher=}} ==Media and management== Al-Suwaidan is a TV personality who has prepared and presented numerous Islamic television shows on Islamic subjects ranging from broadcasting of the Quran, stories of Muhammad, notable women and Andalusian history. His shows have aired on Kuwait television, First Channel, Space Channel and MBC.https://web.archive.org/web/20051127101957/http://www.thedohadebates.com/output/Page29.asp Al-Suwaidan is a TV personality who has prepared and presented numerous Islamic television shows on Islamic subjects ranging from stories of the Prophet, notable women and Andalusian history. His shows have aired on Kuwait television, First Channel, Space Channel and MBC. Al-Suwaidan was formerly the General Manager of [[Al-Resalah Satellite TV]], the brainchild of Saudi businessman Prince [[Al-Waleed bin Talal]]. In August 2013, Prince Talal fired Suwaidan for his role as the leader of the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] in Kuwait. Prince Talal wrote on his [[Twitter account]] that he sacked Tarek Al-Suwaidan "for admitting he belongs to the Brotherhood movement."{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2013/08/18/saudi-prince-muslim-brotherhood/2668443/|title=TV director fired for ties to Muslim Brotherhood|author=AP|date=18 August 2013|work=USA TODAY}} In a letter to Al-Suwaidan, Prince Al Waleed wrote that there was no place for a Muslim Brotherhood member on the channel. Prince Alaweed bin Talal, criticized him as having "extremist inclinations".{{Cite web|title = Kuwaiti preacher barred from Makkah pilgrimage|url = http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/kuwait/kuwaiti-preacher-barred-from-makkah-pilgrimage-1.1238437|website = gulfnews.com|access-date = 2016-01-14}}{{Cite news|title = Saudi Arabia, Kuwait tighten controls on clerics|url = https://www.reuters.com/article/us-gulf-clerics-idUSBRE9AO0B120131125|newspaper = Reuters|date = 2013-11-25|access-date = 2016-01-14}} ==Educational initiatives== Al-Suwaidan was one of the founders of the American Creativity Academy in Kuwait, a private institution that offers an American college-preparatory education within the context of Islamic values.{{cite web|url=http://americancreativityacademy-acareview.blogspot.de|title=American Creativity Academy - ACA Review|author=Ahmed.A|work=americancreativityacademy-acareview.blogspot.de}} He is also one of the founders of AGS (Advanced Generations School) in [[Saudi Arabia]], a "Canadian school with an Islamic identity." Students study English under the Canadian curriculum, and take Islamic and Arabic classes as well.{{citation need|date=November 2014}} Al-Suwaidan has been responsible for the preparation and submission of several courses and lectures to tens of entities in [[Kuwait]], the [[Persian Gulf|Gulf]] and the Arab world, [[Malaysia]], [[Europe]], [[United States|America]] and [[Australia]], and has trained more than 70 thousand trainees in a variety of topics relating to management in an Islamic context.{{citation needed|date=November 2014}} ==Productions== Al-Suwaidan is the author of 54 best-selling books, his most popular being: Iidad Alkada (Preparing Leaders), and spoken word audio tape albums. His album, ''Qasas al Anbiyaa'' (''Stories of the [[Prophets in Islam|Prophets]]'') is the highest-selling Islamic album in the world with well over 2 million copies sold. Additionally, over 3.4 million listeners have downloaded his lectures on the popular Islamic broadcast website "Islamway".{{cite web|url=http://ar.islamway.net/lessons/scholar/69|title=طارق بن محمد السويدان - الدروس - طريق الإسلام|work=islamway.net}}{{citation needed|date=November 2014}} ===Management books=== {| |valign="top"| *Leadership in the {{sic|?|twenty-century}} *How to write a strategic plan ) stand alone( *Test your strategic information *Machine Creativity (Creativity step by step) *Flexible muscles of your brain |valign="top"| *Principles of creativity *Pentagonal loyalty *Time management *Order your life *Market leadership *Learning Organization |valign="top"| *Systematic change in organizations *Industry leader *The art of wonderful diction *Recent trends in management *How to change yourself *Success in life |valign="top"| *Training and creative teaching. *The culture industry - 1. Industry Culture *The culture industry - 2. How do I Read? *The culture industry - 3. What to Read? *The culture industry - 4. Child Reader *Industry Intelligence |} ===Islamic books=== #''Summary of the Islamic belief'' #''Secrets of Fasting'' #''Secrets of Hajj and Umrah'' #''Fasting'' #''The Jews: The Illustrated Encyclopedia'' (2009){{efn|The aim of this online book is to "attest to, through evidence and accounts, that the falsified religion of the Jews, itself, encourages them to practice treason and treachery, and feeds them to make them a special group among humans, and confers upon them the right to exploit others on the most hideous paths of duplicity."{{cite news|last1=Seniguer|first1=Haoues|title=The World's Schizophrenic Attitude Towards Charlie Hebdo|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/haoues-seniguer/world-schizophrenic-charlie-hebdo_b_6473824.html|accessdate=15 January 2016|work=Huffington Post|date=2015-03-17}}}} ==Awards== {{Empty section|date=March 2016|section=}} ==Views and ideology== He supported [[Muslim Brotherhood]] against the [[2013 Egyptian coup d'état]]. He is a member of the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] in Kuwait and has been described in US State Department cables as a "moderate Islamist"."Help cure West's ills, Muslims told", Catherine Porter, ''[[Toronto Star]]'', Monday, January 6, 2003, Ontario edition, Section: News, p. A08{{cite web|url=https://www.wikileaks.org/plusd/cables/05KUWAIT3384_a.html|title=Cable: 05KUWAIT3384_a|work=wikileaks.org}} In 2012 he said "If Islamists start to become tyrants in the countries that were hit by the [[Arab Spring]], we will revolt against them just like we did against their predecessors.” and that “Freedom is a holy right and is one of the principles in Islam ... Freedom is to do and say what a person wishes but in a polite manner and without hurting others.” http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/03/25/203152.html In 2006 he demanded that the [[European Union]], as well as the rest of the world, enact “a law that forbids the insult to religious figures and religious sacred opinions.”{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ecews5f7xts|title=Mohammed Cartoons - Tareq Al-Suweidan|date=7 February 2009|work=YouTube}} He has supported women's rights within Islamic [[sharia]] law and advocated for reforming traditional understanding of Islam.{{cite web|url=http://www.thedohadebates.com/debates/item/indexbae7.html|title=This House believes that Arab women should have full equality with men|work=thedohadebates.com}} Al-Suwaidan is one of the signatories of [[A Common Word Between Us and You]], an open letter by Islamic scholars to [[Christian]] leaders, calling for peace and understanding.{{cite web|url=http://acommonword.com/index.php?lang=en&page=faq#link7|title=A Common Word Between Us and You|work=acommonword.com}}{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4679252|title=Qatar Opens Debate on Thorny Muslim, Arab Issues|date=3 June 2005|work=NPR.org}} Al-Suwaidan has condemned the [[9/11]] terrorists saying "these people are very dangerous to themselves, to the Arab world, to the Islamic world itself, and to Islam itself." Al-Suwaidan is a strong supporter of women's rights in the Middle East and has participated in the Doha Debates arguing in favor of women's political and social rights. He spoke out against forced marriages calling it "un-Islamic."{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YVQhmfe6iiQ|title=BBCDohaDebates - June 1, 2005 - Series 1 Episode 7 (Part 6)|first=|last=BBCDohaDebates|date=27 July 2009|publisher=|via=YouTube}} Al-Suwaidan has also been a harsh critic of the US and the West and at conference of the [[Islamic Circle of North America]] in 2000, Al-Suwaidan said: "We must tell the West that we are extending a hand of peace now, but it will not be so for long." "Even if a civilization is ready to crumble – like the West, with all the characteristics of deterioration of past fallen empires – it will not fall until we, the Muslims, strive to give it that last push, the last straw that will break the camel's back.http://www.theaustralian.com.au/higher-education/mixed-messages-from-touring-muslim-lecturer/story-e6frgcjx-1226386791743 At a meeting of the [[Islamic Association of Palestine]] in Chicago in 2000 Al-Suwiadan said "Palestine will not be liberated but through Jihad. Nothing can be achieved without sacrificing blood. The Jews will meet their end at our hands." He was subsequently banned from the US."Hardline cleric banned in the US will preach to British universities" Patrick Sawer; Philip Sherwell The Sunday Telegraph (London) January 24, 2010 Section: News; Pg. 8 In May 2007, Al-Suwaidan was listed by U.S. federal prosecutors, along with a group of U.S. Muslim Brotherhood members, as an [[unindicted co-conspirator]] in the [[terrorism financing]] case against the [[Holy Land Foundation for Relief and Development]] which was convicted along with its leaders of financing [[Hamas]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/dn/latestnews/stories/112508dnmetholylandverdicts.1e5022504.html?|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081202111922/http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/dn/latestnews/stories/112508dnmetholylandverdicts.1e5022504.html|title=Holy Land Foundation defendants guilty on all counts - News for Dallas, Texas - Dallas Morning News - Latest News|archivedate=2 December 2008|work=dallasnews.com|deadurl=yes|df=}}http://www.investigativeproject.org/documents/case_docs/423.pdf{{cite web|url=http://www.nysun.com/national/islamic-groups-named-in-hamas-funding-case/55778/|title=Islamic Groups Named in Hamas Funding Case|work=nysun.com}} A Federal court subsequently ruled that the list of unindicted co-conspirators should not have been released to the public.{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/news/local-news/20101106-Judge-ruled-prosecutors-should-not-have-6808.ece|title=Judge ruled prosecutors should not have publicly released Holy Land unindicted co-conspirators list|work=dallasnews.com}} In an April 2012 interview for Al-Quds, a TV station affiliated with [[Hamas]], he claimed that since politicians were controlled by money and the media which are controlled by the Jews, only "armed resistance" and not Western aid or Western popular sympathy could change the situation in Palestine and Jerusalem. He also said in the interview that the most dangerous thing facing Muslims is the Jews calling them "the greatest enemy." "http://www.theaustralian.com.au/higher-education/mixed-messages-from-touring-muslim-lecturer/story-e6frgcjx-1226386791743 Al-Suwaidan subsequently denied charges of antisemitism stating, "We are not against the Jews, let this be very clear." He alleged that the comments were based on a report by [[MEMRI]] which he called a "Zionist organization".{{cite web|url=http://muslimvillage.com/2012/06/26/24397/tareq-al-suwaidan-defends-charges-anti-semitism/|title=Tareq Al Suwaidan defends charges of anti-semitism|work=MuslimVillage.com}} In a sermon to Hamas which was later posted on the internet on July 14, 2014, Al-Suwaidan described Israel as "a deviant country...[that] is destined to be eradicated in its entirety," explaining that "We do not demand a ceasefire. Rather, we demand that the rockets continue to be launched until they bow before us." Al-Suwaidan further stated that: {{cquote|All the mothers of the Islamic nation – not only Palestinian mothers – should suckle their babies on the hatred of the sons of Zion. We hate them. They are our enemies. We should instill this in the souls of our children, until a new generation arises and wipes them off the face of the earth...Each and every one of us, when leaving this hall, should be contemplating a plan how to wipe out Israel.".[http://www.memritv.org/clip_transcript/en/4361.htm Kuwaiti Cleric Tareq Al-Suwaidan to Hamas: Do Not Agree to Ceasefire until They Bow Before Us. We Must Contemplate a Plan to Erase Israel], [[MEMRI]], Clip No. 4361 (transcript), July 14, 2014. (video clip [http://www.memritv.org/clip/en/0/0/0/0/0/0/4361.htm available here])[http://www.newsmax.com/RichLowry/Israel/2014/07/25/id/584876/ Hamas Peace Plan Is to Wipe Out Israel] by Rich Lowry, [[Newsmax Media]], July 25, 2014.}} In November 2014, Al-Suwaidan was banned by the Belgium government from attending a Muslim Fair in [[Brussels]] on the basis of the comments made in this sermon. On his Twitter account, Al-Suwaidan wrote, "Under pressure from the Zionist Lobby, the Belgium government decided to prevent me from entering the country despite holding a valid visa."{{Cite web|title = Kuwaiti Muslim scholar denied entry to Belgium|url = https://www.middleeastmonitor.com/news/europe/15101-kuwaiti-muslim-scholar-denied-entry-to-belgium|website = Middle East Monitor - The Latest from the Middle East|access-date = 2016-01-15}} He claims that the reason they denied him entry was his "candid position regarding Zionism and the barbaric crimes of the Israeli occupation". The Belgium government announced that it had decided to prevent Al-Suwaidan from visiting Brussels, because of his "anti-Semitic" remarks in the past. The Belgian Prime Minister and Interior Minister said "This preacher has unacceptable anti-Semitic beliefs and his presence here is a threat to public order."{{cite web|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/afp/141104/belgium-bars-kuwaiti-preacher-alleged-anti-semitism|title=Belgium bars Kuwaiti preacher for alleged anti-Semitism|work=GlobalPost}} Al-Suwaidan used his Twitter account to promote what he calls electronic Jihad. On January 17, 2012, Al Suwaidan tweeted: "I see the need in uniting the efforts of the hackers within the electronic jihad project against the Zionist enemy, and it is an effective and important jihad, and its reward is great – Allah willing." AlSuwaidan: "I Strongly Encourage Young People To Undertake Electronic Jihad... I View This As Better Than 20 Jihad Operations." In a June 4, 2011 interview on [[AlQuds TV]], AlSuwaidan called for armed resistance and electronic jihad against Israel: "The other day, I was asking myself: Why shouldn't I personally go on jihad? First of all, my body cannot tolerate it. Secondly, is what I am doing any less important than jihad? I would like us all to feel that we are in the same trench. There is such a thing as media jihad, political jihad, and a form of jihad that I strongly encourage young people to undertake – electronic jihad. Some of our youth are extremely clever. I hope that a group of hackers will get together, and will wage resistance over the Internet, targeting Israeli and Zionist sites and destroying them electronically.” ===Clashes with Gulf states=== In November 2012 a [[UAE]] police official said that suspects arrested in UAE had met with Kuwaiti Muslim Brotherhood members who are the ‘mentors of other groups’. He said "They hold courses and teach members how to act and resist, such as Tareq Al-Suwaidan. His anti-regime attitude is very clear." {{cite web|url=http://news.kuwaittimes.net/2012/11/12/dubai-top-cop-spews-bile-at-brotherhood-some-kuwaiti-mps-barred-from-uae/ |title=Internet Archive Wayback Machine |work=archive.org |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121117035052/http://news.kuwaittimes.net/2012/11/12/dubai-top-cop-spews-bile-at-brotherhood-some-kuwaiti-mps-barred-from-uae/ |archivedate=2012-11-17 |df= }} In October 2013, Al-Suwaidan tweeted that he had been barred from performing the lesser [[Umrah]] pilgrimage in [[Saudi Arabia]], stating "I have been banned from entering Saudi Arabia solely for my views and my position against the coup in [[Egypt]] and I say that my love for Saudi Arabia and its people is unshaken and that ideas can [never] be banned.”{{cite web|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/kuwait/kuwaiti-preacher-barred-from-makkah-pilgrimage-1.1238437|title=Kuwaiti preacher barred from Makkah pilgrimage|author=Gulf News Report|work=gulfnews.com}} ==Popularity == Al-Suwaidan has authored over 30 books, but his popularity is largely a result of his widespread [[social media]] activity– including: YouTube, Vimeo, iTunes, Facebook, Twitter. He has over 9 million followers on Twitter, as of 12 November 2017. Hundreds of Arabic and English speeches by Al Suwaidan can be found on YouTube where there are excerpts from his appearances on Arab TV channels, as well as speeches delivered in the Middle East and in the West. == See also == {{Portal|Islam|Kuwait}} * [[Mohammed Rateb al-Nabulsi]] * [[Mohamad al-Arefe]] * [[Islam in Kuwait]] * [[Al-Resalah Satellite TV]] == Notes == {{notelist}} ==References== ==External links== *[http://www.suwaidan.com Tareq Al-Suwaidan's official website] {{en icon}} and {{ar icon}} * {{Twitter}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Suwaidan, Tareq}} [[Category:University of Tulsa alumni|Al-Suwaiden, Tareq]] [[Category:Pennsylvania State University alumni|Al-Suwaidan, Tareq]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Kuwaiti Sunni clerics]] [[Category:Kuwaiti Sunni Muslims]] [[Category:Kuwaiti businesspeople]] [[Category:Kuwaiti writers]] [[Category:Kuwaiti Muslim Brotherhood members]] [[Category:Kuwaiti broadcasters]] [[Category:Kuwaiti expatriates in the United States]] [[Category:Kuwaiti historians]] [[Category:Kuwaiti engineers]] [[Category:20th-century Kuwaiti businesspeople]] [[Category:21st-century Kuwaiti businesspeople]]

{{Infobox book | name = The Goal: A Process of Ongoing Improvement | title_orig = | translator = | image = The-goal-bookcover.jpg | caption = Front Cover | author = [[Eliyahu M. Goldratt]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = | language = [[English language|English]] | series = | subject = | genre = | publisher = [[North River Press (publisher)|North River Press]] | release_date = {{plainlist| * 1984 First Edition * 1986 Revised First Edition * 1992 Revised Second Edition * 2004 Revised Third Edition * 2014 Fourth Revised (30th Anniversary) Edition }} | english_release_date = | media_type = [[Softcover]] | pages = 384 | isbn = 978-0-88427-178-9 | dewey= 823/.914 22 | congress= PR9510.9.G64 G6 2004 | oclc= 56194659 | preceded_by = | followed_by = [[It's Not Luck]] }}
'''''The Goal''''' is a [[business fable|management-oriented novel]] by [[Eliyahu M. Goldratt]], a business consultant known for his [[Theory of Constraints]], and [http://jeffcox.com/books.html Jeff Cox], a best selling author and co-author of multiple management-oriented novels.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.simonandschuster.co.uk/authors/Jeff-Cox/1306788|title=Jeff Cox|website=Simon & Schuster|language=en|access-date=2017-05-25}}</ref> '''''The Goal''''' was originally published in 1984 and has since been revised and republished. This book can be used for case studies in operations management, with a focus geared towards the Theory of Constraints, bottlenecks and how to alleviate them, and applications of these concepts in real life.<ref>[https://www.routledge.com/products/9780566086656 A summary of ''The Goal'' by Gower Publishing]</ref> It is used in management colleges to teach students about the importance of strategic capacity planning and constraint management. [[Time (magazine)|''Time Magazine'']] listed the book as one of "The 25 Most Influential Business Management Books.<ref>{{Cite news|title = The 25 Most Influential Business Management Books|url = http://content.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2086680_2086683_2087672,00.html|newspaper = Time|date = 2011-08-09|access-date = 2016-02-20|issn = |first = Nate|last = Rawlings}}</ref>
==Setting== Like other books by Goldratt and by Cox, ''The Goal'' is written as a piece of fiction. The main character is Alex Rogo, who manages a production plant owned by UniCo Manufacturing, where everything is always behind schedule and things are looking dire.<ref>{{Cite news|title = “Then Why Did We Buy the NCX-10?”|url = http://www.slate.com/articles/business/operations/2012/06/the_goal_eli_goldratt_s_gripping_thriller_about_operations_theory_.html|newspaper = Slate|date = 2012-06-08|access-date = 2016-02-20|issn = 1091-2339|language = en-US|first = Seth|last = Stevenson}}</ref> At the beginning of the book, Bill Peach, a company executive, tells Alex that he has three months to turn operations at his plant around from being unprofitable and unreliable to being successful.<ref>[http://maaw.info/ArticleSummaries/ArtSumTheGoal.htm A chapter-by-chapter summary of ''The Goal'']</ref> His distant acquaintance, Jonah (a physicist), whom many believe represents Goldratt himself, helps him solve the company's problems through a series of telephone calls and short meetings. A second story line is introduced involving Alex's marital life. Perhaps surprisingly, Jonah's concepts are also applied successfully in this alternative story line.
==Bottlenecks== The book goes on to point out the role of [[wikt:bottleneck|bottleneck]]s ([[Theory of Constraints#Constraints|constraints]]) in a manufacturing process, and how identifying them not only makes it possible to reduce their impact, but also yields a useful tool for measuring and controlling the flow of materials. Alex and his team identify the bottlenecks in their process and immediately begin to implement changes to help increase capacity and speed up production. In response to questions about the logic of using outdated technology in modern manufacturing, Alex's team brought in an old machine they received for free (which had previously been used at their plant in conjunction with two other machines) in order to increase the capacity of the NCX-10 machine, which had been identified as one of the two bottlenecks. Further more, they identified processes at the [[heat treating|heat treat]], identified as their second bottleneck, that caused massive delays in their getting product through the heat-treat and which had also caused some products to be heat-treated multiple times (to make softer and then harder again) instead of just once or not at all.
==Socratic method== In the book, Jonah teaches Alex Rogo by using the [[Socratic method]]. Throughout the book, whenever a meeting or telephone call dialogue happens with Jonah he poses a question to Alex Rogo or a member of his crew which in turn causes them to talk amongst themselves to come up with a solution to their problem. When Alex Rogo is with his wife, he finds the Socratic method to be a way to fix his marriage which he then uses, with his crew, to come up with the five steps they should use to fix problems in the plant which ultimately leads him and Lou to think up the three things every division manager, the position Rogo is promoted to, should be able to do.
==Characters== * Alex Rogo - main character, manufacturing plant manager * Bill Peach - division vice-president * Fran - Alex's secretary * Jonah - advisor, Alex's old physics professor. Helps Alex with almost all decisions * Lou - chief accountant/ plant controller * Stacey - the plant inventory manager * Julie Rogo - Alex Rogo's wife * Bob Donovan - production manager * Ralph Nakamura - data processing manager * Herbie - the bottleneck and the solution * Dave - Alex Rogo's son * Sharon - Alex Rogo's daughter * Mike O'Donnel - union rep * Ethan Frost - division controller * Eddie - Second shift supervisor * Johnny Jons - marketing director *Hilton Smyth - Assistant Division Contoller *Bucky Burnside - President of UniCo's biggest customer
==See also== {{portal|Novels}} *[https://www.toc-goldratt.com/en/product/the-goal-movie-how-to-version The Goal (Movie)] *[[Theory of Constraints]] *[[List of project management topics]] *[[List of management topics]] *[[Special:BookSources/9781942788294|The Phoenix Project: A Novel about IT, DevOps, and Helping Your Business Win]] An adaptation of '''The Goal''' for the modern IT world.
==References== {{Reflist}} *{{cite book |first=Eliyahu M. |last=Goldratt |author2=Jeff Cox |title=The Goal: A Process of Ongoing Improvement |isbn=0-88427-061-0 |publisher=North River Press |location=Great Barrington, MA.}}
==External links== * [http://www.tocinstitute.org/the-goal-summary.html Chapter-wise summary of ''The Goal'' at the Theory of Constraints Institute website]

The '''Training Within Industry''' ('''TWI''') service was created by the [[United States Department of War]], running from 1940 to 1950 within the [[War Manpower Commission]]. The purpose was to provide consulting services to war-related industries whose personnel were being [[Conscription|conscripted]] into the [[United States Army|US Army]] at the same time the War Department was issuing orders for additional [[matériel]]. It was apparent that the shortage of trained and skilled personnel at precisely the time they were needed most would impose a hardship on those industries, and that only improved methods of job training would address the shortfall.<ref>[http://www.ibiblio.org/hyperwar/ATO/Admin/WarProgram/charts/WarProgram-20.jpg]</ref> By the end of [[World War II]], over 1.6 million workers in over 16,500 plants had received a certification. The program continued post-war in Europe and Asia, where it aided reconstruction. It is most notable in the business world for inspiring the concept of [[kaizen]] in Japan.
==Overview==
The four basic training programs (10-hour sessions) developed by TWI were developed by experts on loan from [[Private sector|private industry]]. Because of the intensity of the situation, a large number of experimental methods were tried and discarded. This resulted in a distilled, concentrated set of programs. Each program had introductory programs called "Appreciation Sessions" that were used to sell the programs to top management and introduce the programs to middle management of a company. Each program also had 'Train-the-Trainer' programs and handbooks called "Institute Conductor's Manual" for the master trainers.<ref name = dinero-foundations>{{cite book | last = Dinero | first = Donald | title = Training Within Industry: The Foundation of Lean | year = 2005 | location = Portland, OR | publisher = Productivity Press | isbn = 9781563273070 | url = }}</ref> The TWI Service also developed a number of "Staff Only" training programs to support staff development and to improve the implementation success.
The TWI trainers had to be invited to a factory in order to present their material. In order to market the service, they developed the Five Needs of the Supervisor: every supervisor needs to have Knowledge of the Work, Knowledge of Responsibility, Skill in Instructing, Skill in Improving Methods, and Skill in Leading.<ref name = dinero-foundations/> Each program was based on Charles Allen's 4-point method of Preparation, Presentation, Application, and Testing.
The 10-hour Sessions were:
* Job Instruction (JI) - a course that taught trainers (supervisors and experienced workers) to train inexperienced workers faster. The instructors were taught to break down jobs into closely defined steps, show the procedures while explaining the key points and the reasons for the key points, then watch the student attempt under close coaching, and finally to gradually wean the student from the coaching. The course emphasized the credo, "If the worker hasn't learned, the instructor hasn't taught".<ref name = dinero-foundations/> At the request of enterprises outside of manufacturing, variations to the JI program were developed for hospitals, office and farms. * Job Methods (JM) - a course that taught workers to objectively evaluate the efficiency of their jobs and to methodically evaluate and suggest improvements. The course also worked with a job breakdown, but students were taught to analyze each step and determine if there were sufficient reason to continue to do it in that way by asking a series of pointed questions. If they determined some step could be done better by eliminating, combining, rearranging, or simplifying, they were to develop and apply the new method by selling it to the "boss" and co-workers, obtaining approval based on safety, quality, quantity, and cost, standardizing the new method, and giving credit.<ref name = dinero-foundations/> * Job Relations (JR) - a course that taught supervisors to deal with workers effectively and fairly. It emphasized the lesson, "People Must Be Treated As Individuals".<ref name = dinero-foundations/> * Program Development (PD) - the meta-course that taught those with responsibility for the training function to assist the line organization in solving production problems through training.<ref name = dinero-foundations/>
There was also a short-lived course that taught union personnel (UJR) to work effectively with management.<ref name = dinero-foundations/>
=== Additional programs ===
Internal training programs were; "Management Contact Manual" (1944) - a formal training course on how to sell the TWI programs to management, "How to get Continuing Results from TWI Programs in a Plant" (1944) - this training program was the out-growth of two years of practical experimentation and experience on what it took to have a successful implementation of TWI.
* Job Safety (JS) - While the US TWI Service chose to not develop a JS program, stating that safety was part of every job, Canada led the way with the first variant that was closely modeled on the JI program. This program was offered to England, which declined and developed a JS program that focused on discovery of risk and resolution. Copies of the British programs were circulated in Japan starting about 1948.<ref>(Reference: US National Archive SCAP collection)</ref> * Problem Solving (PS) - There are two different programs using similar names. The TWI Foundation released their PS program in 1946 and follows the standard J program format. TWI, Inc. released their program in 1955 and is a much more comprehensive program that revolves around using the JI, JR and JM programs for problem solving.<ref>(Reference: US National Archive SCAP collection; US National Archive TWIF Collection)</ref> * Discussion Leading (DL) - This is an early work in developing what is now recognized as facilitation skills. TWIF also produced a variant of this program called Conference Leading.
=== Expansion to other nations ===
There were several groups that had an impact in the expansion of the TWI programs around the world - [[United States Department of State|US State Department]], [[United States Army|US Army]], [[British Ministry of Labour,]] [[International Labour Organization|International Labor Organization]] (ILO) and [[Standard Oil]].<ref>(Reference: US National Archives ; British National Archives; ILO Archives Geneva)</ref> In 1944, the British Ministry of Labour sent [[Frank Perkins (British Politician)|Frank Perkins]] to the US to evaluate the TWI programs.<ref>(Reference: British National Archives - Perkins Report - folder LAB 18-139)</ref> In the summer of 1944, Perkins returned to England to establish a similar program. The British Ministry of Labour actively promoted the TWI programs, listing 65 countries in addition to the US and England where TWI was known to be in use as of 1959.<ref>(Reference: British National Archive - folder LAB 18-724)</ref> Expansion into Europe was led by Standard Oil, which led the translation efforts of the manuals into native languages. Some European TWI activity was done under the [[Marshall Plan]] by "Visiting Experts" (VE), with limited success. It was the later work by the ILO using the Standard Oil translations and re-translation efforts that established the TWI programs in Europe. The ILO TWI training program in [[Bangalore|Bangalore India]] has the distinction of training the first Japanese about 1947.<ref>(Reference: US National Archive SCAP collection - Japan; ILO Archives Geneva)</ref>
=== Post war ===
Although the TWI program funding for application of the programs in the USA by the government ended in 1945, the US government did fund the introduction to the war-torn nations of Europe and Asia. Several private groups continued to provide TWI in the US and abroad. Channing Dooley, Walter Dietz, Mike Kane and [[Bill Conover]] (collectively known as "the Four Horsemen") continued the development of the 'J' programs by establishing the TWI Foundation.<ref name = dinero-foundations/> This group was responsible for continuing the spread of TWI throughout Europe and Asia. The Director of one of the district offices established TWI, Inc., and was hired by the US Government to provide TWI training in Japan. It was especially well received in Japan, where TWI formed the basis of the [[kaizen]] culture in industry. ''Kaizen'', known by such names as ''Quality Circles'' in the West, was successfully harnessed by [[Toyota Motor Corporation]] in conjunction with the [[Lean manufacturing|Lean]] or [[Just In Time (business)|Just In Time]] principles of [[Taiichi Ohno]]. In the Foreword to Dinero's book "Training Within Industry", John Shook relates a story in which a Toyota trainer brought out an old copy of a TWI service manual to prove to him that American workers at [[NUMMI]] could be taught using the "Japanese" methods used at Toyota. Thus, TWI was the forerunner of what is today regarded as a Japanese creation.<ref name = dinero-foundations/>
==See also== * [[Kaizen]] * [[Toyota Production System]] * [[General McArthur#Occupation of Japan|General McArthur's Occupation of Japan]]

{{Infobox university |name = UNSW Business School |image = UNSW Business School logo.png |image_size = 300px |established = 2006 |type = [[Public university|Public]] |parent = [[University of New South Wales]] | administrative_staff = 218 |students = 13,012 | city = [[Sydney]], Australia | coordinates ={{coord|-33.916867|151.229897|display=title, inline}} |former_names = Australian School of Business |website = [http://www.business.unsw.edu.au/ business.unsw.edu.au] |affiliations = [[Australian Graduate School of Management]] |faculty = 350+ }}[[Image:Australian School of Business UNSW.jpg|thumb|Faculty building]] The '''UNSW Business School''' at the [[University of New South Wales]] is a business school located in [[Sydney]], Australia. It is a [[University and college admission|highly selective]], [[Reputation|prestigious]] and [[Leading University|world leader]] in business education.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.business.unsw.edu.au/degrees-courses|title=Degrees & Courses|work=UNSW Business School|access-date=2018-06-17|language=en}}</ref> UNSW business school leads in research and rankings of its educational programs.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.business.unsw.edu.au/research/research-grants/rankings|title=Rankings|work=UNSW Business School|access-date=2018-06-17|language=en}}</ref> The school offers 42 programs, including 26 undergraduate and 26 specialist master's degrees, as well as six [[Master of Business Administration|MBA]] and executive programs through the [[Australian Graduate School of Management]].
== History == Accountancy, the first school of the Faculty of Commerce, began operations in 1955.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.recordkeeping.unsw.edu.au/documents/Accountancy-A249.pdf|title=Agency Details - School of Accountancy/Accounting|accessdate=May 18, 2017}}</ref> The Faculty of Commerce was then formed formally in 1957 - later re-named the Faculty of Commerce and Economics in 1988.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.recordkeeping.unsw.edu.au/documents/A22-FCE.pdf|title=Agency Details - Faculty of Commerce/Commerce and Economics|accessdate=May 18, 2017}}</ref> In 1977 the [[Australian Graduate School of Management]] (AGSM) was established.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.recordkeeping.unsw.edu.au/documents/A403-AGSM.pdf|title=Agency Details - Australian Graduate School of Management|accessdate=May 18, 2017}}</ref>
In 2006, the Faculty of Commerce and Economics and the AGSM merged to form what was initially known as the Faculty of Business, before being renamed the Australian School of Business (ASB) in 2007. In 2014 the ASB was renamed the UNSW Business School.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.recordkeeping.unsw.edu.au/documents/A317-ASB.pdf|title=Agency Details - Faculty of Business/Australian School of Business/UNSW Business School|accessdate=May 18, 2017}}</ref>
Professor Chris Styles became Dean of UNSW Business School at UNSW Australia on 1 July 2014.
The Business School is guided by its Business Advisory Council, comprising 51 industry leaders and chaired by Nicholas Moore, CEO and Managing Director of [[Macquarie Group|Macquarie Group Ltd]].{{Citation needed|date=January 2017}}
There are eight disciplinary schools within the UNSW Business School, in addition to the [[Australian Graduate School of Management]]. Including: School of Accounting, School of Banking & Finance, School of Economics, School of Information Systems, School of Management, School of Marketing, School of Risk & Actuarial, School of Taxation & Business Law.
== Enrolments == In 2014, the UNSW Business School had 14,519 students enrolled: 8,283 undergraduate and 5,854 postgraduate students. 2% of its students are in research.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=https://www.business.unsw.edu.au/About-Site/Documents/pocketstats-2014.pdf|accessdate=April 24, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150404131659/https://www.business.unsw.edu.au/About-Site/Documents/pocketstats-2014.pdf|archivedate=April 4, 2015}}</ref>
30% of all UNSW Business School students<ref name="autogenerated1" /> are international students, with the largest proportion of international students coming from China, Hong Kong and Indonesia.
==Rankings== From 2007 to 2014 the UNSW Business School was ranked by the ''[[Financial Times]]'' as having the best full-time MBA program in the country.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.business.unsw.edu.au/about|title=Pocket Stats UNSW Business School|last=|first=|date=|newspaper=|access-date=2017-07-31|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> The school's primary undergraduate degree, the [[Bachelor of Commerce]], has the highest Australian [[Australian Tertiary Admission Rank|high school entry score]] for a business undergraduate program in Australia.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.business.unsw.edu.au/about|title=About|work=UNSW Business School|access-date=2017-08-04|language=en}}</ref> The 2018 [[QS World University Rankings]] ranked UNSW equal 10th in the world for Accounting and Finance (1st in Australia).<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.topuniversities.com/university-rankings/university-subject-rankings/2018/accounting-finance|title=Accounting & Finance|last=|first=|date=2018-03-17|work=Top Universities|access-date=2018-03-17|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> In [[Academic Ranking of World Universities|ARWU]] 2018 Global Academic Subject Rankings UNSW is ranked 16th in the world for Finance (1st in Australia) and 50th in the world for Management (1st in Australia).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.shanghairanking.com/Shanghairanking-Subject-Rankings/finance.html|title=ShanghaiRanking's Global Ranking of Academic Subjects 2018 - Finance {{!}} Shanghai Ranking - 2018|website=www.shanghairanking.com|access-date=2018-07-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.shanghairanking.com/Shanghairanking-Subject-Rankings/management.html|title=ShanghaiRanking's Global Ranking of Academic Subjects 2018 - Management {{!}} Shanghai Ranking - 2018|website=www.shanghairanking.com|access-date=2018-07-17}}</ref> UNSW is also ranked 15th in the world for Commerce, Management, Tourism and Services.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.urapcenter.org/2017_Fields/Commerce-Management-Tourism_and_Services.php|title=URAP - University Ranking by Academic Performance|last=info@urapcenter.org|first=All: URAP Lab. [www.urapcenter.org]; e-mail:|website=www.urapcenter.org|access-date=2018-06-17}}</ref> According to latest 2018 [[Korea University Business School|KUBS]] worldwide business research rankings UNSW is ranked 1st worldwide for Finance and 11th globally for Management for the last five year period (2013-2017), in 2018 in the same ranking it is ranked 11th in the world (1st in Australia) for business and among the leading business schools world wide.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://kubsrankings.korea.ac.kr/sub/ranking-area.html|title=The KUBS Worldwide Business Research Rankings|website=kubsrankings.korea.ac.kr|access-date=2018-09-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://kubsrankings.korea.ac.kr/sub/ranking-worldwide.html|title=The KUBS Worldwide Business Research Rankings|last=|first=|date=|website=kubsrankings.korea.ac.kr|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-02}}</ref> The latest Australian Graduate Survey in 2012 found that UNSW has educated more CEOs of Australia’s top 50 companies than any other university in Australia.<ref name=":1">{{cite web|url=https://www.business.unsw.edu.au/students/why-choose-us/rankings|title=Our rankings | UNSW Australia Business School|date=|website=Business.unsw.edu.au|accessdate=2016-02-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://kubsrankings.korea.ac.kr/sub/ranking-area.html|title=The KUBS Worldwide Business Research Rankings|website=kubsrankings.korea.ac.kr|access-date=2018-09-02}}</ref> UNSW has produced more technology entrepreneurs in the past 15 years than any other Australian university, and has the largest number of millionaire alumni of any other university in Australia.<ref name=":1" />
==Professional accreditation== The UNSW Business School was awarded EQUIS accreditation in June 2010 for five years. It has also been awarded accreditation from AACSB International.
Its programs are also accredited by professional bodies in most disciplines, including: * CPA Australia * Chartered Accountants Australia + New Zealand (CAANZ) (formerly known as Institute of Chartered Accountants in Australia, ICAA) * Institute of Public Accountants (IPA) * Institute of Actuaries of Australia * Institute of Actuaries (London) * Australian Human Resources Institute (AHRI) * Australian Computer Society (ACS) * Australian Market and Social Research Society (AMSRS) * Australian Marketing Institute (AMI) The School is also a signatory to the UN Principles of Responsible Management Education (PRME).
==Alumni and industry links== {{see|List of University of New South Wales alumni}} The UNSW Business School has over 83,000 alumni.<ref name=":1" />
In 2014, the UNSW Business School provided 242 students with scholarships, adding up to a total value of $3,087,752. Additionally, 64 students received prizes valued at a total of $32,000.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
